the plastic of the housing and lid is very durable , however the thin plastic where the clips enter is an exception . the odds are that you will crack some of these areas as you remove the lid . do not fret , as the lid will stay closed even with just a few of the clips . the fact that there are fourteen speaks to the over-engineering at mercedes benz .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by un-clipping the motor housing cover. There are a total of fourteen clips. Five on each of the long side, and two on top and bottom of the housing. The plastic of the housing and lid is very durable, however the thin plastic where the clips enter is an exception. The odds are that you will crack some of these areas as you remove the lid. Do not fret, as the lid will stay closed even with just a few of the clips. The fact that there are fourteen speaks to the over-engineering at Mercedes Benz.

Lines.Text: as the clips come lose use a metal spudger to separate the cover from the body of the housing .
it will eventually lift off and can be set aside .

Steps.Text_raw: As the clips come lose use a metal spudger to separate the cover from the body of the housing. It will eventually lift off and can be set aside.

Lines.Text: make note of the rubber seal that goes around the body of the motor in a channel , sealing the cover to the body . if this seal is old a dry rotted it will need to be replaced , or a proper liquid sealant will need to be used in its place , if the motor is being re-used .

Steps.Text_raw: Make note of the rubber seal that goes around the body of the motor in a channel, sealing the cover to the body. If this seal is old a dry rotted it will need to be replaced, or a proper liquid sealant will need to be used in its place, if the motor is being re-used.

Lines.Text: the basic internal components of the motor are as follows :
control board
electric motor
plastic drive gears
antenna shaft

to operate the antenna up and down , the electric motor turns in the appropriate direction which turns the worm gear . the worm gear tuns the upper plastic drive gear . that spins the lower plastic gear which then moves the ribbed plastic cable inside the cable housing below the gears , all of which you will see later .

Steps.Text_raw: The basic internal components of the motor are as follows: Control board Electric motor Plastic drive gears Antenna shaft To operate the antenna up and down, the electric motor turns in the appropriate direction which turns the worm gear. The worm gear tuns the upper plastic drive gear. That spins the lower plastic gear which then moves the ribbed plastic cable inside the cable housing below the gears, all of which you will see later.

Lines.Text: you can see the accumulation of dirt and debris on these gears . if the antenna shaft had not seized it would only have been a matter of time before the gears wore or broke .

Steps.Text_raw: You can see the accumulation of dirt and debris on these gears. If the antenna shaft had not seized it would only have been a matter of time before the gears wore or broke.

Lines.Text: continue disassembly by unscrewing the two phillips screws holding the electric motor in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue disassembly by unscrewing the two Phillips screws holding the electric motor in place.

Lines.Text: remove the two rubber buffers that keep the case cover separated properly from the motors and gears .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two rubber buffers that keep the case cover separated properly from the motors and gears.

Lines.Text: use a metal spudger or flat blade screwdriver to remove the c-clip holding the gears to the bushing and shaft .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a metal spudger or flat blade screwdriver to remove the c-clip holding the gears to the bushing and shaft.

Lines.Text: use a metal spudger to gently begin lifting the gears from the shaft .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a metal spudger to gently begin lifting the gears from the shaft.

Lines.Text: as the gears begin to lift , the electric motor will likely pop loose . it can be rested off to the side ; it is wired to the control board so it cannot be removed fully at this time .

Steps.Text_raw: As the gears begin to lift, the electric motor will likely pop loose. It can be rested off to the side; it is wired to the control board so it cannot be removed fully at this time.

Lines.Text: continue lifting the gears out of their housing until they are free .
as you can see , there are actually two gears in the housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue lifting the gears out of their housing until they are free. As you can see, there are actually two gears in the housing.

Lines.Text: the gears can be separated by simply pulling them apart with your hands .
make note of which gear is the upper gear , and of the alignment of the gears and the spring together .

Steps.Text_raw: The gears can be separated by simply pulling them apart with your hands. Make note of which gear is the upper gear, and of the alignment of the gears and the spring together.

Lines.Text: lift the metal gear bushing up and off of the housing and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the metal gear bushing up and off of the housing and set it aside.

Lines.Text: unscrew the phillips head screw that helps hold the antenna shaft to the body .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the Phillips head screw that helps hold the antenna shaft to the body.

Lines.Text: remove the outer sleeve on the shaft from the body by rotating it counter-clockwise .
once loose from the body it can be pulled up the antenna shaft and out of the way .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the outer sleeve on the shaft from the body by rotating it counter-clockwise. Once loose from the body it can be pulled up the antenna shaft and out of the way.

Lines.Text: pull the ribbed plastic cable connected to the antenna shaft out of the body of the motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the ribbed plastic cable connected to the antenna shaft out of the body of the motor.

Lines.Text: now you can remove the gear and cable housing . it seems to work best to rotate the housing up and in the direction of the antenna shaft opening before angling it up and pulling it out of the motor body .

Steps.Text_raw: Now you can remove the gear and cable housing. It seems to work best to rotate the housing up and in the direction of the antenna shaft opening before angling it up and pulling it out of the motor body.

Lines.Text: this leaves the lower cable retainer in place .
lift it up and out .
note the thin metal washer at the center of this .

Steps.Text_raw: This leaves the lower cable retainer in place. Lift it up and out. Note the thin metal washer at the center of this.

Lines.Text: remove the three rubber buffers .
remove the gear shaft .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three rubber buffers. Remove the gear shaft.

Lines.Text: you now have an empty motor housing , besides the control board .
this disassembly does not cover the electric motor as everything is in plain sight .
worm gear
motor
small belt driven pulleys for worm gear

Steps.Text_raw: You now have an empty motor housing, besides the control board. This disassembly does not cover the electric motor as everything is in plain sight. Worm gear Motor Small belt driven pulleys for worm gear

Title: 2007 Chevy Aveo Indicator light bulb Replacement

Lines.Text: here is a view of the left tail light assembly
open the rear hatch , ( or trunk if it is a sedan ) . on the inside of the assembly are two retaining screws . remove those
both screws are 6x3 /4 inch

Steps.Text_raw: Here is a view of the left tail light assembly Open the rear hatch,( or trunk if it is a sedan). On the inside of the assembly are two retaining screws. Remove those both screws are #6x3/4 inch

Lines.Text: here is a view of the assembly with the screws removed .

insert some sort of prying tool between the tail light assembly and the body , just below the crease in the body and pry to the rear of the vehicle . a snap will be felt/heard as the plastic stud releases
move the prying tool to above 1 1 /2 inch above the bottom of the assembly . insert it between the assembly and body and gently pry toward the rear of the vehicle . this should free the second stud .

Steps.Text_raw: Here is a view of the assembly with the screws removed. Insert some sort of prying tool between the tail light assembly and the body, just below the crease in the body and pry to the rear of the vehicle. a snap will be felt/heard as the plastic stud releases Move the prying tool to above 1 1/2 inch above the bottom of the assembly. Insert it between the assembly and body and gently pry toward the rear of the vehicle. This should free the second stud.

Lines.Text: now just pull the assembly straight back .
avoid pulling the assembly to one side or another , that can snap the plastic studs
locate the burned out bulb . in this case it was the indicator light . rotate the bulb sockets in a counterclockwise direction .
pull the sockets straight out of the tail light assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Now just pull the assembly straight back. Avoid pulling the assembly to one side or another, that can snap the plastic studs Locate the burned out bulb. In this case it was the indicator light. Rotate the bulb sockets in a counterclockwise direction. Pull the sockets straight out of the tail light assembly.

Subject: Indicator light bulb

Title: Mercedes W123 Brake Line, Front Driver's Side Replacement

Lines.Text: before you can begin you'll need to remove the front driver's wheel for easier access to the parts to be removed .
next you'll want to drain the brake fluid from the front driver's side caliper .
loosen the bleed screw on the caliper and allow the fluid to drain in to a pan .

Steps.Text_raw: Before you can begin you'll need to remove the front driver's wheel for easier access to the parts to be removed. Next you'll want to drain the brake fluid from the front driver's side caliper. Loosen the bleed screw on the caliper and allow the fluid to drain in to a pan.

Lines.Text: spray the connection of the hard brake line and the soft rubber brake hose with penetrating lubricant .

this is a good time to consider also changing the soft rubber brake hose since it will already be halfway disconnected and the fluid drained . for more on this , and for more tips on disconnecting the hard lines from the rubber hose , the rubber brake hose replacement guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Spray the connection of the hard brake line and the soft rubber brake hose with penetrating lubricant. This is a good time to consider also changing the soft rubber brake hose since it will already be halfway disconnected and the fluid drained. For more on this, and for more tips on disconnecting the hard lines from the rubber hose, [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/Mercedes+W123+Brake+Hose+Replacement/22767|see the rubber brake hose replacement guide.]

Lines.Text: place a 14 mm line wrench or open end wrench on the soft rubber brake line . use it to hold the soft rubber line to prevent it from twisting .
place a 11 mm line wrench or open end wrench on the hard line nut . use it to loosen this nut to back the connection out of the soft rubber line .

Steps.Text_raw: Place a 14mm line wrench or open end wrench on the soft rubber brake line. Use it to hold the soft rubber line to prevent it from twisting. Place a 11mm line wrench or open end wrench on the hard line nut. Use it to loosen this nut to back the connection out of the soft rubber line.

Lines.Text: under the hood , locate the connection for the driver's side front hard line on the master cylinder , just below the brake fluid reservoir . the line is the rear line on the driver's side of the master cylinder .
use an 11 mm line wrench or open end wrench to loosen the nut on the hard line at the master cylinder .

Steps.Text_raw: Under the hood, locate the connection for the driver's side front hard line on the master cylinder, just below the brake fluid reservoir. The line is the rear line on the driver's side of the master cylinder. Use an 11mm line wrench or open end wrench to loosen the nut on the hard line at the master cylinder.

Lines.Text: the hard line on this side goes down through a rubber grommet in the fender .
pull the line up and out of this grommet .
you can now begin to install the replacement brake line .
since you opened up the brake system to the air you will need to bleed the system before driving . never drive a car after working on the brake lines without first bleeding it properly . guide

Steps.Text_raw: The hard line on this side goes down through a rubber grommet in the fender. Pull the line up and out of this grommet. You can now begin to install the replacement brake line. Since you opened up the brake system to the air you will need to bleed the system before driving. Never drive a car after working on the brake lines without first bleeding it properly. [guide|21442|See the brake flush/bleeding guide for guidance on this process.]

Subject: Brake Line, Front Driver's Side

Title: Mercedes W123 Brake Line, Rear Replacement

Lines.Text: before beginning to remove the hard brake lines you'll need to drain the fluid from your rear caliper ( s ) . you only need to drain the fluid from the side you're working on ; if you're doing both lines , drain both .
to drain them loosen the bleed screw and let the fluid drip in to a pan .

Steps.Text_raw: Before beginning to remove the hard brake lines you'll need to drain the fluid from your rear caliper(s). You only need to drain the fluid from the side you're working on; if you're doing both lines, drain both. To drain them loosen the bleed screw and let the fluid drip in to a pan.

Lines.Text: spray the area where the hard brake lines and the soft rubber hoses connect at the rear of the car with penetrating lubricant .

Steps.Text_raw: Spray the area where the hard brake lines and the soft rubber hoses connect at the rear of the car with penetrating lubricant.

Lines.Text: find the brake line distributor at the rear of the car where the two hard lines split off to each wheel . it is just up behind the driver's side axle .
spray this with penetrating lubricant .
the components shown include :
hard line to front of car , connects to master cylinder .
hard line to rear driver's side caliper .
hard line to rear passenger side caliper .
distributor .

Steps.Text_raw: Find the brake line distributor at the rear of the car where the two hard lines split off to each wheel. It is just up behind the driver's side axle. Spray this with penetrating lubricant. The components shown include: Hard line to front of car, connects to master cylinder. Hard line to rear driver's side caliper. Hard line to rear passenger side caliper. Distributor.

Lines.Text: this guide will start on the driver's side line . you may begin on either side .
begin by removing the soft rubber hose where it connects to the hard line .
for information on removing these soft rubber hoses the rubber brake hose removal guide . consider replacing these hoses at this time since you already have them disconnected halfway .

Steps.Text_raw: This guide will start on the driver's side line. You may begin on either side. Begin by removing the soft rubber hose where it connects to the hard line. For information on removing these soft rubber hoses [http://www.ifixit.com/Guide/Mercedes+W123+Rubber+Brake+Hose+Replacement/21345|see the rubber brake hose removal guide]. Consider replacing these hoses at this time since you already have them disconnected halfway.

Lines.Text: use an 11 mm line wrench or open end wrench to loosen the connection for the driver's side brake line at the distributor .
this line can then be removed from the car .

Steps.Text_raw: Use an 11mm line wrench or open end wrench to loosen the connection for the driver's side brake line at the distributor. This line can then be removed from the car.

Lines.Text: repeat with the passenger side line . loosen it from the distributor .

note that this line may be routed through a bracket that holds both the hard brake line and the hard fuel line from the fuel tank in place with a rubber buffer . this is located directly up from and behind the rear differential .

if you find this on your car , loosen the 10 mm bolt on the bracket . you do not need to fully remove the bracket , just loosen it enough that it releases the brake line . it can then be pulled out of the car .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat with the passenger side line. Loosen it from the distributor. Note that this line may be routed through a bracket that holds both the hard brake line and the hard fuel line from the fuel tank in place with a rubber buffer. This is located directly up from and behind the rear differential. If you find this on your car, loosen the 10mm bolt on the bracket. You do not need to fully remove the bracket, just loosen it enough that it releases the brake line. It can then be pulled out of the car.

Lines.Text: your distributor will now look like this .

Steps.Text_raw: Your distributor will now look like this.

Lines.Text: you can now begin installing the new lines .
starting with the passenger side line , note that it should go in behind the rubber drain hose just inside the rear fender .
the driver's side simply sets in place as the old line did .

Steps.Text_raw: You can now begin installing the new lines. Starting with the passenger side line, note that it should go in behind the rubber drain hose just inside the rear fender. The driver's side simply sets in place as the old line did.

Lines.Text: clean all the end connections of the hard lines , at the distributor and at the brackets for the soft rubber hose connection , with brake cleaner to remove any dirt . you do not want to introduce dirt in to your brake system .
let the brake cleaner dry . you can then begin reconnecting the soft rubber hoses , and can connect the hard lines to the distributor .

before driving your car you will need to bleed the system to remove the air that has been introduced . never drive your car after doing work on the brake lines without first bleeding it properly . the brake flush/bleeding guide for help with this .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean all the end connections of the hard lines, at the distributor and at the brackets for the soft rubber hose connection, with brake cleaner to remove any dirt. You do not want to introduce dirt in to your brake system. Let the brake cleaner dry. You can then begin reconnecting the soft rubber hoses, and can connect the hard lines to the distributor. Before driving your car you will need to bleed the system to remove the air that has been introduced. Never drive your car after doing work on the brake lines without first bleeding it properly. [http://www.ifixit.com/Guide/Mercedes+W123+Brake+Fluid+Flush-Bleeding/21442|See the brake flush/bleeding guide for help with  this.]

Subject: Brake Line, Rear

Title: Mercedes W123 Brake Pad, Front Replacement

Lines.Text: the pad removal process in this guide is performed with the caliper off of the vehicle . the installation process is documented with it on the vehicle . both procedures can be done with the caliper on the vehicle . the calipers were off of this car for cleaning , since the soft rubber hoses were being replaced too .
you'll need to remove your wheels to perform this work .
the first step is to remove the brake pad wear sensors . first , disconnect them from the sensor harness bolted to the caliper .
then use a needle nose plier to remove the sensors from the old pads . the wires may break as they did on this set , but you can still grab the sensor body to remove it .
these sensors cannot be re-used . they should be replaced with the pads .

Steps.Text_raw: The pad removal process in this guide is performed with the caliper off of the vehicle. The installation process is documented with it on the vehicle. Both procedures can be done with the caliper on the vehicle. The calipers were off of this car for cleaning, since the soft rubber hoses were being replaced too. You'll need to remove your wheels to perform this work. The first step is to remove the brake pad wear sensors. First, disconnect them from the sensor harness bolted to the caliper. Then use a needle nose plier to remove the sensors from the old pads. The wires may break as they did on this set, but you can still grab the sensor body to remove it. These sensors cannot be re-used. They should be replaced with the pads.

Lines.Text: next use a punch and hammer to tap the pad spring retaining springs out of the caliper .

note that there are several styles of springs and pins , depending on the brand of caliper and the age of your w123. some pins have cotters holding them in place that you would need to remove before punching them out . guide

Steps.Text_raw: Next use a punch and hammer to tap the pad spring retaining springs out of the caliper. Note that there are several styles of springs and pins, depending on the brand of caliper and the age of your W123. Some pins have cotters holding them in place that you would need to remove before punching them out. [guide|21531|See the rear brake pad replacement guide to see this style.]

Lines.Text: once you have punched the pins out part of the way they may be pulled the rest of the way out with a needle nose plier .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have punched the pins out part of the way they may be pulled the rest of the way out with a needle nose plier.

Lines.Text: with the pins removed the pad retaining spring will come free and can be set aside .
note that it's possible this spring is under some tension and could pop out .

Steps.Text_raw: With the pins removed the pad retaining spring will come free and can be set aside. Note that it's possible this spring is under some tension and could pop out.

Lines.Text: the old pads can now be slid out of the caliper . with the caliper off of the car they can slip out either direction . with the caliper on the car they will only slip out away from the brake rotor .
if your pads look this dirty and rusty upon removal , consider removing the calipers for inspection and cleaning .

Steps.Text_raw: The old pads can now be slid out of the caliper. With the caliper off of the car they can slip out either direction. With the caliper on the car they will only slip out away from the brake rotor. If your pads look this dirty and rusty upon removal, consider removing the calipers for inspection and cleaning.

Lines.Text: now that the pads are removed you will need to move the pistons in the caliper back so that the new , thicker pads will fit in .

first , you should remove a bit of brake fluid from the system . as the old pads wore down , there was room for more fluid in the system and the level was likely topped off . with the new thicker pads in place there will be more fluid in the system that there is room for , potentially .
begin with this process by removing the cap on the brake fluid reservoir .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the pads are removed you will need to move the pistons in the caliper back so that the new, thicker pads will fit in. First, you should remove a bit of brake fluid from the system. As the old pads wore down, there was room for more fluid in the system and the level was likely topped off. With the new thicker pads in place there will be more fluid in the system that there is room for, potentially. Begin with this process by removing the cap on the brake fluid reservoir.

Lines.Text: then lift the screen out of the neck of the reservoir .

Steps.Text_raw: Then lift the screen out of the neck of the reservoir.

Lines.Text: suction out a few ounces of brake fluid . you can use a suction tool as shown , or a clean turkey baster . just never use the turkey baster in the kitchen again !
do not suction the reservoir dry ! you would need to bleed the system if this happens .

Steps.Text_raw: Suction out a few ounces of brake fluid. You can use a suction tool as shown, or a clean turkey baster. Just never use the turkey baster in the kitchen again! Do not suction the reservoir dry! You would need to bleed the system if this happens.

Lines.Text: with some fluid removed and the top left off of the brake fluid reservoir , use a large pry tool to gently pry the pistons back in to the body of the caliper .
always use the flat surface of the pry , never the tip , and try to push the piston back in as straight and evenly as possible .
alternately , you can purchase the proper brake caliper piston compression tool from mercedes . . . but this pry bar technique works if you are careful .
repeat this on all four pistons . watch the brake fluid level as your proceed to ensure it does not overflow the reservoir . remove more if necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: With some fluid removed and the top left off of the brake fluid reservoir, use a large pry tool to gently pry the pistons back in to the body of the caliper. Always use the flat surface of the pry, never the tip, and try to push the piston back in as straight and evenly as possible. Alternately, you can purchase the proper brake caliper piston compression tool from Mercedes...but this pry bar technique works if you are careful. Repeat this on all four pistons. Watch the brake fluid level as your proceed to ensure it does not overflow the reservoir. Remove more if necessary.

Lines.Text: cover the back of each new brake pad with a very light coat of brake pad grease/anti-squeal coating .
be very careful to not get any of this grease on the front of the pads , where the pad material is .

Steps.Text_raw: Cover the back of each new brake pad with a very light coat of brake pad grease/anti-squeal coating. Be very careful to not get any of this grease on the front of the pads, where the pad material is.

Lines.Text: slide the pads in to the caliper with the pad material facing in towards the rotor .
if the pads are not sliding in , try prying the piston back a bit further .
the pads should be seated fully in to the caliper until they stop .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the pads in to the caliper with the pad material facing in towards the rotor. If the pads are not sliding in, try prying the piston back a bit further. The pads should be seated fully in to the caliper until they stop.

Lines.Text: place the retaining spring back on top of the pads .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the retaining spring back on top of the pads.

Lines.Text: re-insert the pins as far as you can by hand .
the pins should be on top of the retaining spring .

Steps.Text_raw: Re-insert the pins as far as you can by hand. The pins should be on top of the retaining spring.

Lines.Text: tap them in with a hammer , finishing with a punch to get them all the way in .

these pins are a compression fit . your pins may have cotters that hold them in place . if you had to remove cotters in order to get the pins out , be sure to use cotters in the same manner when you re-install them .

Steps.Text_raw: Tap them in with a hammer, finishing with a punch to get them all the way in. These pins are a compression fit. Your pins may have cotters that hold them in place. If you had to remove cotters in order to get the pins out, be sure to use cotters in the same manner when you re-install them.

Lines.Text: then push your new brake pad sensors in to the holes made for them in the pads . there is one hole on each pad . make sure the sensor seats in the clip on the top of the pad securely .
then push the tips of the sensor in to the sensor harness that is bolted to the caliper .
be certain to top off the brake fluid reservoir before driving , if necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: Then push your new brake pad sensors in to the holes made for them in the pads. There is one hole on each pad. Make sure the sensor seats in the clip on the top of the pad securely. Then push the tips of the sensor in to the sensor harness that is bolted to the caliper. Be certain to top off the brake fluid reservoir before driving, if necessary.

Subject: Brake Pad, Front

Title: Mercedes W123 Brake Pads, Rear Replacement

Lines.Text: the pad removal process in this guide is performed with the caliper off of the vehicle . the installation process is documented with it on the vehicle . both procedures can be done with the caliper on the vehicle . the calipers were off of this car for cleaning , since the soft rubber hoses were being replaced too .
you'll need to remove your wheels to perform this work .
start by removing the cotters from the pins that hold the pad retaining springs in place . not all calipers will use cotters in the pins ; some may use compression fit pins . guide

Steps.Text_raw: The pad removal process in this guide is performed with the caliper off of the vehicle. The installation process is documented with it on the vehicle. Both procedures can be done with the caliper on the vehicle. The calipers were off of this car for cleaning, since the soft rubber hoses were being replaced too. You'll need to remove your wheels to perform this work. Start by removing the cotters from the pins that hold the pad retaining springs in place. Not all calipers will use cotters in the pins; some may use compression fit pins. [guide|21526|See the front brake pad replacement guide to see how these are removed.]

Lines.Text: then use a punch to hammer out the pins .
the springs will come out after the pin is removed .
this picture shows one pin and spring already removed . the second is being removed .
the pads can then be pulled out .

Steps.Text_raw: Then use a punch to hammer out the pins. The springs will come out after the pin is removed. This picture shows one pin and spring already removed. The second is being removed. The pads can then be pulled out.

Lines.Text: now that the pads are removed you will need to move the pistons in the caliper back so that the new , thicker pads will fit in .

first , you should remove a bit of brake fluid from the system . as the old pads wore down , there was room for more fluid in the system and the level was likely topped off . with the new thicker pads in place there will be more fluid in the system that there is room for , potentially .
begin with this process by removing the cap on the brake fluid reservoir .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the pads are removed you will need to move the pistons in the caliper back so that the new, thicker pads will fit in. First, you should remove a bit of brake fluid from the system. As the old pads wore down, there was room for more fluid in the system and the level was likely topped off. With the new thicker pads in place there will be more fluid in the system that there is room for, potentially. Begin with this process by removing the cap on the brake fluid reservoir.

Lines.Text: then lift the screen out of the neck of the reservoir .

Steps.Text_raw: Then lift the screen out of the neck of the reservoir.

Lines.Text: suction out a few ounces of brake fluid . you can use a suction tool as shown , or a clean turkey baster . just never use the turkey baster in the kitchen again !
do not suction the reservoir dry ! you would need to bleed the system if this happens .

Steps.Text_raw: Suction out a few ounces of brake fluid. You can use a suction tool as shown, or a clean turkey baster. Just never use the turkey baster in the kitchen again! Do not suction the reservoir dry! You would need to bleed the system if this happens.

Lines.Text: with some fluid removed and the top left off of the brake fluid reservoir , use a large pry tool to gently pry the pistons back in to the body of the caliper .
always use the flat surface of the pry , never the tip , and try to push the piston back in as straight and evenly as possible .
alternately , you can purchase the proper brake caliper piston compression tool from mercedes . . . but this pry bar technique works if you are careful .
repeat this on all four pistons . watch the brake fluid level as your proceed to ensure it does not overflow the reservoir . remove more if necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: With some fluid removed and the top left off of the brake fluid reservoir, use a large pry tool to gently pry the pistons back in to the body of the caliper. Always use the flat surface of the pry, never the tip, and try to push the piston back in as straight and evenly as possible. Alternately, you can purchase the proper brake caliper piston compression tool from Mercedes...but this pry bar technique works if you are careful. Repeat this on all four pistons. Watch the brake fluid level as your proceed to ensure it does not overflow the reservoir. Remove more if necessary.

Lines.Text: cover the back of each new brake pad with a very light coat of brake pad grease/anti-squeal coating .
be very careful to not get any of this grease on the front of the pads , where the pad material is .

Steps.Text_raw: Cover the back of each new brake pad with a very light coat of brake pad grease/anti-squeal coating. Be very careful to not get any of this grease on the front of the pads, where the pad material is.

Lines.Text: slide the pads in to the calipers . make sure the brake pad material is facing towards the rotor . the holes on top of the pads need to face away from the rotor .
if the pads are not sliding in , try prying the piston back a bit further .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the pads in to the calipers. Make sure the brake pad material is facing towards the rotor. The holes on top of the pads need to face away from the rotor. If the pads are not sliding in, try prying the piston back a bit further.

Lines.Text: insert the springs in the same way they were removed .

then insert the pins . it can be tricky to get the pin through the holes in the second pad especially if the pad is in the caliper a bit too far . it can help to use an allen key or something similarly long and slender to align the pads .
then , simply chase the allen key out with the pin .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the springs in the same way they were removed. Then insert the pins. It can be tricky to get the pin through the holes in the second pad especially if the pad is in the caliper a bit too far. It can help to use an allen key or something similarly long and slender to align the pads. Then, simply chase the allen key out with the pin.

Lines.Text: then use some strong wire or cotters to secure the ends of the pin in place .
be certain to top off the brake fluid reservoir before driving , if necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: Then use some strong wire or cotters to secure the ends of the pin in place. Be certain to top off the brake fluid reservoir before driving, if necessary.

Subject: Brake Pads, Rear

Title: Mercedes W123 Brake Caliper, Front Replacement

Lines.Text: you will need to remove your wheels before you start .
before beginning on removal of the calipers you should drain the brake fluid from them .
this is done through the bleed screw on each caliper .
loosen this and let it drain in to a proper drain pan .

Steps.Text_raw: You will need to remove your wheels before you start. Before beginning on removal of the calipers you should drain the brake fluid from them. This is done through the bleed screw on each caliper. Loosen this and let it drain in to a proper drain pan.

Lines.Text: several items need to be disconnected from the front caliper before it can be removed .
the first is the wiring harness for the brake pad sensors .
use a 10 mm wrench to remove the bolt and washer holding it to the caliper .
then unplug the ends of the sensors from the harness .
let the harness hang up and out of the way .

Steps.Text_raw: Several items need to be disconnected from the front caliper before it can be removed. The first is the wiring harness for the brake pad sensors. Use a 10mm wrench to remove the bolt and washer holding it to the caliper. Then unplug the ends of the sensors from the harness. Let the harness hang up and out of the way.

Lines.Text: next you will need to remove the soft rubber brake hoses .

you will have to start by disconnecting the rubber hose from the hard line connection up inside the fender well . then you can loosen it from the caliper and remove the line . this takes a 14 mm wrench for the soft hose and an 11 mm wrench for the brake line .
for more information and tips on removing these lines , guide
speaking of the rubber hoses , this is a great time to replace them with new parts if they show signs of age since they are already off of the car .

Steps.Text_raw: Next you will need to remove the soft rubber brake hoses. You will have to start by disconnecting the rubber hose from the hard line connection up inside the fender well. Then you can loosen it from the caliper and remove the line. This takes a 14mm wrench for the soft hose and an 11 mm wrench for the brake line. For more information and tips on removing these lines, [guide|21345|see the brake hose replacement guide.] Speaking of the rubber hoses, this is a great time to replace them with new parts if they show signs of age since they are already off of the car.

Lines.Text: next use a large ratchet wrench with a 19 mm socket to remove the two bolts that hold the caliper to the steering knuckle .
these bolts are in very tight , and had thread locker on them from the factory , so you may need a very long wrench or a breaker bar in order to get enough leverage to remove these two bolts .
hold on to the caliper as you remove the second of the two bolts so it doesn't fall when you remove the bolt .

Steps.Text_raw: Next use a large ratchet wrench with a 19mm socket to remove the two bolts that hold the caliper to the steering knuckle. These bolts are in very tight, and had thread locker on them from the factory, so you may need a very long wrench or a breaker bar in order to get enough leverage to remove these two bolts. Hold on to the caliper as you remove the second of the two bolts so it doesn't fall when you remove the bolt.

Lines.Text: after you have completed your work on the caliper , such as removing the old pads , and cleaning them up , they can be re-installed . or , if you have new calipers , this is the time to install them .

before installing the caliper bolts be sure to apply some thread locker to them . use the blue thread locker than can be removed with hand tools , not the red thread locker as that needs heat to remove .
hold the caliper up on the rotor and line the holes in the caliper up with the bolt holes in the steering knuckle . get the first bolt started by hand .
then , start the second bolt by hand as well . doing so helps ensure they do not become cross-threaded .

Steps.Text_raw: After you have completed your work on the caliper, such as removing the old pads, and cleaning them up, they can be re-installed. Or, if you have new calipers, this is the time to install them. Before installing the caliper bolts be sure to apply some thread locker to them. Use the blue thread locker than can be removed with hand tools, not the red thread locker as that needs heat to remove. Hold the caliper up on the rotor and line the holes in the caliper up with the bolt holes in the steering knuckle. Get the first bolt started by hand. Then, start the second bolt by hand as well. Doing so helps ensure they do not become cross-threaded.

Lines.Text: then tighten the bolts down until they seat against the caliper . do not tighten them all the way down with the normal ratchet wrench .

Steps.Text_raw: Then tighten the bolts down until they seat against the caliper. Do not tighten them all the way down with the normal ratchet wrench.

Lines.Text: switch your 19 mm socket to a large 1 /2 inch drive torque wrench . torque both of the caliper bolts down to 115 nm/85 lb-ft .

Steps.Text_raw: Switch your 19mm socket to a large 1/2 inch drive torque wrench. Torque both of the caliper bolts down to 115 nm/85 lb-ft.

Lines.Text: re-attach the sensor harness and insert the sensors back in to the connectors on the harness .

Steps.Text_raw: Re-attach the sensor harness and insert the sensors back in to the connectors on the harness.

Lines.Text: re-attach the brake hoses , starting at the calipers and then attaching them to the hard lines .
before you drive the car you must bleed your brakes of air since you opened up the system . never drive the car without bleeding after you've worked on the lines , or calipers . guide

Steps.Text_raw: Re-attach the brake hoses, starting at the calipers and then attaching them to the hard lines. Before you drive the car you must bleed your brakes of air since you opened up the system. Never drive the car without bleeding after you've worked on the lines, or calipers. [guide|21442|See the brake flush/bleeding guide.]

Lines.Text: an important note - if you are removing and replacing the front and rear calipers at the same time be sure to keep the front and rear bolts separate .
this is because they are different designs . while you can use the rear bolts on the front calipers , the front bolts will not fit on the rear calipers .
front bolt , with a shoulder
rear bolt , no shoulder , all thread

Steps.Text_raw: An important note - if you are removing and replacing the front and rear calipers at the same time be sure to keep the front and rear bolts separate. This is because they are different designs. While you can use the rear bolts on the front calipers, the front bolts will not fit on the rear calipers. Front bolt, with a shoulder Rear bolt, no shoulder, all thread

Title: Mercedes W123 Brake Caliper, Rear Replacement

loosen this and let it drain in to a proper drain pan .

these bolts are in very tight , and had thread locker on them from the factory , so you may need a very long wrench or a breaker bar in order to get enough leverage to remove these two bolts .
hold on to the caliper as you remove the second of the two bolts so it doesn't fall when you remove the bolt .

These bolts are in very tight, and had thread locker on them from the factory, so you may need a very long wrench or a breaker bar in order to get enough leverage to remove these two bolts. Lines.Text: after you have completed your work on the caliper , such as removing the old pads , and cleaning them up , they can be re-installed . or , if you have new calipers , this is the time to install them .

before installing the caliper bolts be sure to apply some thread locker to them . use the blue thread locker than can be removed with hand tools , not the red thread locker as that needs heat to remove .
hold the caliper up on the rotor and line the holes in the caliper up with the bolt holes in the steering knuckle . get the first bolt started by hand .
then , start the second bolt by hand as well . doing so helps ensure they do not become cross-threaded .

Steps.Text_raw: After you have completed your work on the caliper, such as removing the old pads, and cleaning them up, they can be re-installed. Or, if you have new calipers, this is the time to install them. Before installing the caliper bolts be sure to apply some thread locker to them. Use the blue thread locker than can be removed with hand tools, not the red thread locker as that needs heat to remove. Hold the caliper up on the rotor and line the holes in the caliper up with the bolt holes in the steering knuckle. Get the first bolt started by hand. Then, start the second bolt by hand as well. Doing so helps ensure they do not become cross-threaded.

Lines.Text: then tighten the bolts down until they seat against the caliper . do not tighten them all the way down with the normal ratchet wrench .

Steps.Text_raw: Then tighten the bolts down until they seat against the caliper. Do not tighten them all the way down with the normal ratchet wrench.

Lines.Text: switch your 19 mm socket to a large 1 /2 inch drive torque wrench . torque both of the caliper bolts down to 115 nm/85 lb-ft .

Steps.Text_raw: Switch your 19mm socket to a large 1/2 inch drive torque wrench. Torque both of the caliper bolts down to 115 nm/85 lb-ft.

Lines.Text: re-attach the brake hoses , starting at the calipers and then attaching them to the hard lines .
before you drive the car you must bleed your brakes of air since you opened up the system . never drive the car without bleeding after you've worked on the lines , or calipers . guide

Steps.Text_raw: Re-attach the brake hoses, starting at the calipers and then attaching them to the hard lines. Before you drive the car you must bleed your brakes of air since you opened up the system. Never drive the car without bleeding after you've worked on the lines, or calipers. [guide|21442|See the brake flush/bleeding guide.]

Lines.Text: an important note - if you are removing and replacing the front and rear calipers at the same time be sure to keep the front and rear bolts separate .
this is because they are different designs . while you can use the rear bolts on the front calipers , the front bolts will not fit on the rear calipers .
front bolt , with a shoulder
rear bolt , no shoulder , all thread

Steps.Text_raw: An important note - if you are removing and replacing the front and rear calipers at the same time be sure to keep the front and rear bolts separate. This is because they are different designs. While you can use the rear bolts on the front calipers, the front bolts will not fit on the rear calipers. Front bolt, with a shoulder Rear bolt, no shoulder, all thread

Subject: Brake Caliper, Rear

Title: Mercedes W123 Brake Disc, Rear Replacement

Lines.Text: you will first need to remove your wheel to complete the remainder of this job .
then unbolt the two 19 mm bolts on the back of the caliper . they are in very tightly and held in by thread locker , you may need a long wrench or breaker bar to remove these .

lift the caliper off of the rotor and hang it with a wire hanger from the sway bar or other strong point on the car . do not let the caliper hang by the brake hose , this can damage the hose leading to an unsafe driving condition .
or , optionally , remove the caliper from the car for cleaning and new pad install . see the guide guides .

the rear rotor can then be simply pulled off . if it seems to be stuck to the rear hub , tap around the outside of the rotor with the wooden handle of a hammer , or a rubber mallet , to break it loose .

Steps.Text_raw: You will first need to remove your wheel to complete the remainder of this job. Then unbolt the two 19mm bolts on the back of the caliper. They are in very tightly and held in by thread locker, you may need a long wrench or breaker bar to remove these. Lift the caliper off of the rotor and hang it with a wire hanger from the sway bar or other strong point on the car. Do not let the caliper hang by the brake hose, this can damage the hose leading to an unsafe driving condition. Or, optionally, remove the caliper from the car for cleaning and new pad install. See the [guide|21534|caliper replacement] and [guide|21531|break pad replacement] guides. The rear rotor can then be simply pulled off. If it seems to be stuck to the rear hub, tap around the outside of the rotor with the wooden handle of a hammer, or a rubber mallet, to break it loose.

Lines.Text: with the rotor off the rear hub is exposed . it may be quite rusty like this . if the rotor was seized to the hub it was because of this rust .

Steps.Text_raw: With the rotor off the rear hub is exposed. It may be quite rusty like this. If the rotor was seized to the hub it was because of this rust.

Lines.Text: use a fine grit sandpaper , and optionally a power sander , to work around the flat surface of the hub to remove rust .
then use the sandpaper to remove rust from the raised portion at the center of the hub .
the area around the lug bolt holes is recessed slightly and does not contact the rotors so it does not to be fully de-rusted .
spray the hub down with brake cleaner to remove the dust .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a fine grit sandpaper, and optionally a power sander, to work around the flat surface of the hub to remove rust. Then use the sandpaper to remove rust from the raised portion at the center of the hub. The area around the lug bolt holes is recessed slightly and does not contact the rotors so it does not to be fully de-rusted. Spray the hub down with brake cleaner to remove the dust.

Lines.Text: now apply a light coat of anti-seize to the surfaces on the hub that contact the rotor .
this will help prevent the new rotor from seizing to the surface of the hub the next time you need to remove it .
do not get anti-seize in to the lug bolt holes ! this could lead to the lug bolts backing out while you are driving , allowing the wheel to fall off .

Steps.Text_raw: Now apply a light coat of anti-seize to the surfaces on the hub that contact the rotor. This will help prevent the new rotor from seizing to the surface of the hub the next time you need to remove it. Do not get anti-seize in to the lug bolt holes! This could lead to the lug bolts backing out while you are driving, allowing the wheel to fall off.

Lines.Text: now set the new rotor in place . there is a small raised pin on the hub that the rotor has a corresponding hole for . this ensure the rotor is installed correctly aligned with the bolt holes .
spray both sides of the new rotor down with brake cleaner to remove any oils from the factory or from your gloves .

Steps.Text_raw: Now set the new rotor in place. There is a small raised pin on the hub that the rotor has a corresponding hole for. This ensure the rotor is installed correctly aligned with the bolt holes. Spray both sides of the new rotor down with brake cleaner to remove any oils from the factory or from your gloves.

Lines.Text: now re-install the caliper . make sure to put blue thread locker on the caliper bolts .
torque the caliper bolts down to 115 nm / 85 lb-ft

Steps.Text_raw: Now re-install the caliper. Make sure to put blue thread locker on the caliper bolts. Torque the caliper bolts down to 115 nm / 85 lb-ft

Subject: Brake Disc, Rear

Title: Mercedes W123 Diesel Oil and Filter Change, Under Car

Lines.Text: to start , remove the oil cap . this will allow the oil to drain out of the engine faster .

Steps.Text_raw: To start, remove the oil cap. This will allow the oil to drain out of the engine faster.

Lines.Text: now underneath the car loosen the oil drain bolt . it takes a 13 mm socket .
be aware that once the bolt comes loose the oil will come out very quickly . have a drain pan ready underneath the oil drain hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Now underneath the car loosen the oil drain bolt. It takes a 13mm socket. Be aware that once the bolt comes loose the oil will come out very quickly. Have a drain pan ready underneath the oil drain hole.

Lines.Text: clean up your drain pan bolt . if you are unsure about how old the pan bolt is , it's best to replace it . consider replacing it every five or six oil changes . it's cheap insurance .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean up your drain pan bolt. If you are unsure about how old the pan bolt is, it's best to replace it. Consider replacing it every five or six oil changes. It's cheap insurance.

Lines.Text: wearing gloves during an oil change is a very good idea . as mentioned before , it stains everything . as you can see , even after wiping up , these latex gloves are stained . imagine what it would do to your skin .

Steps.Text_raw: Wearing gloves during an oil change is a very good idea. As mentioned before, it stains everything. As you can see, even after wiping up, these latex gloves are stained. Imagine what it would do to your skin.

Lines.Text: next , loosen the two nuts that hold the lid on the oil filter housing . they take a 13 mm socket just like the drain plug .

Steps.Text_raw: Next, loosen the two nuts that hold the lid on the oil filter housing. They take a 13mm socket just like the drain plug.

Lines.Text: once the nuts are loosened and removed , lift the cover up and out of the filter housing . remove the filter as well .

be careful as you remove the cover . it can be easy to disconnect some of the vacuum lines that cross over and next to the oil filter housing . if this happens you may cause issues with the vacuum system such as the locks , the shut-off valve , or transmission .

note that when you remove the oil filter , the bit of oil left in the housing will then drain from the drain plug . make sure to leave the drain pan underneath until you re-install the drain plug towards the end of the guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the nuts are loosened and removed, lift the cover up and out of the filter housing. Remove the filter as well. Be careful as you remove the cover. It can be easy to disconnect some of the vacuum lines that cross over and next to the oil filter housing. If this happens you may cause issues with the vacuum system such as the locks, the shut-off valve, or transmission. Note that when you remove the oil filter, the bit of oil left in the housing will then drain from the drain plug. Make sure to leave the drain pan underneath until you re-install the drain plug towards the end of the guide.

Lines.Text: make sure to keep the oil filter in a suitable container . it will slowly drip dirty oil .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure to keep the oil filter in a suitable container. It will slowly drip dirty oil.

Lines.Text: the new oil filter kit should come with the filter itself , a choice of new crush washers for the drain plug bolt , and a new large o-ring gasket for the oil filter housing cover .
it's generally recommended to use the copper crush washer . copper is a soft metal that crushes well for a good seal .

Steps.Text_raw: The new oil filter kit should come with the filter itself, a choice of new crush washers for the drain plug bolt, and a new large o-ring gasket for the oil filter housing cover. It's generally recommended to use the copper crush washer. Copper is a soft metal that crushes well for a good seal.

Lines.Text: it is never a bad time to check parts before installing them . this oil filter was slightly crushed at the bottom during shipping . another one was used instead .

Steps.Text_raw: It is never a bad time to check parts before installing them. This oil filter was slightly crushed at the bottom during shipping. Another one was used instead.

Lines.Text: replace the rubber o-ring gasket around the lid of the oil filter housing cover . never re-use the old one .
use a small needle nose plier or a small flat blade screwdriver to help remove the old gasket .
lightly coat the new gasket with some of the new motor oil to help it seal properly .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the rubber o-ring gasket around the lid of the oil filter housing cover. Never re-use the old one. Use a small needle nose plier or a small flat blade screwdriver to help remove the old gasket. Lightly coat the new gasket with some of the new motor oil to help it seal properly.

Lines.Text: check the o-rings at the tip of the oil filter housing shaft . there are two of them . if they are hardened , or no longer round , they should be replaced . proper o-rings can be found in any metric o-ring set .
it is good practice to replace these every third or fourth oil change as preventative maintenance .
the ones shown here are very flat , and brittle . they had to be broken off as all of their elasticity was gone . they had been neglected for some time , and they were doing little good as a seal .

Steps.Text_raw: Check the o-rings at the tip of the oil filter housing shaft. There are two of them. If they are hardened, or no longer round, they should be replaced. Proper o-rings can be found in any metric o-ring set. It is good practice to replace these every third or fourth oil change as preventative maintenance. The ones shown here are very flat,  and brittle. They had to be broken off as all of their elasticity was gone. They had been neglected for some time, and they were doing little good as a seal.

Lines.Text: install the new filter on the housing lid shaft . then insert the filter in to the housing and snug the lid down with the two nuts you removed in step 5.

Steps.Text_raw: Install the new filter on the housing lid shaft. Then insert the filter in to the housing and snug the lid down with the two nuts you removed in step 5.

Lines.Text: now install the drain plug , in this case a new one , with a new crush washer .
while you may re-use the drain plug several times , never re-use the crush washer . it comes with the oil filter , so there's simply no reason .

Steps.Text_raw: Now install the drain plug, in this case a new one, with a new crush washer. While you may re-use the drain plug several times, never re-use the crush washer. It comes with the oil filter, so there's simply no reason.

Lines.Text: it's time to put in fresh oil . use a diesel rated oil .

consult your owner's manual for what viscosity to use based on your climate . where this car is located , 15 w40 works year round but a thinner oil such as 0 w40 could be helpful for cold starts in very cold climates .

start by putting in about 5 or 5 and 1 /2 quarts . wait a few minutes to let it run down to the oil sump . then put the oil cap on and start the engine . make sure oil pressure shows on the gauge fairly quickly . then let it run for about 1 minute . this will fill the filter housing back up with oil .

then turn off the car and check the oil level . if it's low , add no more than 1 /2 quart at a time until it's full . it will take between 6 and 6 and 1 /2 quarts . if you want some guidance on checking oil level guide
never over-fill a diesel engine with oil . it can lead to catastrophic engine failure due to a runaway engine scenario .

Steps.Text_raw: It's time to put in fresh oil. Use a diesel rated oil. Consult your owner's manual for what viscosity to use based on your climate. Where this car is located, 15w40 works year round but a thinner oil such as 0w40 could be helpful for cold starts in very cold climates. Start by putting in about 5 or 5 and 1/2 quarts. Wait a few minutes to let it run down to the oil sump. Then put the oil cap on and start the engine. Make sure oil pressure shows on the gauge fairly quickly. Then let it run for about 1 minute. This will fill the filter housing back up with oil. Then turn off the car and check the oil level. If it's low, add no more than 1/2 quart at a time until it's full. It will take between 6 and 6 and 1/2 quarts. If you want some guidance on checking oil level [guide|20572|see the oil level check guide.] Never over-fill a diesel engine with oil. It can lead to catastrophic engine failure due to a runaway engine scenario.

Lines.Text: these are the stock horns you are looking for . one is located on the left-side of the radiator ( when looking at the car ) , while the other one is next to the air intake / water tank .

both horns are identical in terms of disassembly/replacement . the one mounted near the radiator is a bit harder to access , since the hex bolt is obscured by a frame -- but it's not that much more difficult to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: These are the [stock] horns you are looking for. One is located on the left-side of the radiator (when looking at the car), while the other one is next to the air intake / water tank. Both horns are identical in terms of disassembly/replacement. The one mounted near the radiator is a bit harder to access, since the hex bolt is obscured by a frame -- but it's not that much more difficult to remove.

Lines.Text: use a 12 mm wrench to remove the bolt holding the horn in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a 12 mm wrench to remove the bolt holding the horn in place.

Lines.Text: unplug the power connector from the horn , and use a wire stripper to expose a bare portion of the wire . the 20 ga hole seemed the best fit for this purpose .

the piaa horns have their power/ground connections on top of the horn , so the stock wire won't be long enough . at the same time , the ground cables that come with the horns are too long -- which is a perfect hack in this case !
snip about 4 of the ground cable wire ( the 1 /4 female spade connector side ) and use a butt connector to attach it to the horn's power wire .
it may be a good idea to insulate the connection with some electrical tape after it's been crimped properly .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the power connector from the horn, and use a wire stripper to expose a bare portion of the wire. The "20 ga" hole seemed the best fit for this purpose. The PIAA horns have their power/ground connections on top of the horn, so the stock wire won't be long enough. At the same time, the ground cables that come with the horns are too long -- which is a perfect hack in this case! Snip about 4" of the ground cable wire (the 1/4" female spade connector side) and use a butt connector to attach it to the horn's power wire. It may be a good idea to insulate the connection with some electrical tape after it's been crimped properly.

Lines.Text: now you should have a shortened ground cable with a bare wire on one end , and that half-loop connector on the other .
attach another 1 /4 female spade connector to the end of the ground cable , and plug it into the ''lower'' of the two male spade connectors on the piaa horn .

Steps.Text_raw: Now you should have a shortened ground cable with a bare wire on one end, and that half-loop connector on the other. Attach another 1/4" female spade connector to the end of the ground cable, and plug it into the ''lower'' of the two male spade connectors on the PIAA horn.

Lines.Text: the factory bolt is a bit larger in diameter than the half-circle connector will allow -- unless it is expanded ! so insert a needle-nose plier into the center for the connector and then spread it apart in order to accommodate the bolt .
route the bolt through the horn's mounting hole .
screw the bolt / ground wire / horn assembly into the factory mounting hole .

Steps.Text_raw: The factory bolt is a bit larger in diameter than the half-circle connector will allow -- unless it is expanded! So insert a needle-nose plier into the center for the connector and then spread it apart in order to accommodate the bolt. Route the bolt through the horn's mounting hole. Screw the bolt / ground wire / horn assembly into the factory mounting hole.

Lines.Text: plug in the dc power line into the top male connector of the horn . the final wiring / horn assembly can be seen in the first image .
once you're done with the first horn , the second should be the same exact procedure -- so go get 'em !

Steps.Text_raw: Plug in the DC power line into the top male connector of the horn. The final wiring / horn assembly can be seen in the first image. Once you're done with the first horn, the second should be the same exact procedure -- so go get 'em!

Lines.Text: so that's it ! here's a before-and-after horn comparison , so you get an idea of the sound difference .
i don't believe the piaas are that much more loud , but they are definitely a nicer sounding setup than the stock honkers .

Steps.Text_raw: So that's it! Here's a before-and-after horn comparison, so you get an idea of the sound difference. I don't believe the PIAAs are that much more loud, but they are definitely a nicer sounding setup than the stock honkers.

Title: How to Change Mercedes W123 Power Steering Fluid and Filter

Lines.Text: jack up the front of the car so you can turn the steering wheel while the car is stationary .
guide , if you need guidance on this .

Steps.Text_raw: Jack up the front of the car so you can turn the steering wheel while the car is stationary. [guide|22770|See the guide on jacking up your car], if you need guidance on this.

Lines.Text: to start the process of changing your power steering fluid , you'll need to remove the lid on the pump reservoir .
if you want guidance on this , and on checking the fluid level , guide

Steps.Text_raw: To start the process of changing your power steering fluid, you'll need to remove the lid on the pump reservoir. If you want guidance on this, and on checking the fluid level, [guide|20570|see the guide on checking power steering fluid level.]

Lines.Text: with the lid removed you can see that this fluid is a bit low , and is also very dark/dirty .

Steps.Text_raw: With the lid removed you can see that this fluid is a bit low, and is also very dark/dirty.

Lines.Text: remove the nut holding down the spring and plastic retainer , if present . on some cars , there is just a spring as shown in the second picture which should be removed .
the nut on this car is a 10 mm .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the nut holding down the spring and plastic retainer, if present. On some cars, there is just a spring as shown in the second picture which should be removed. The nut on this car is a 10mm.

Lines.Text: now use your fluid extractor , or turkey baster ( never use it in the kitchen again ! ) to remove enough fluid to get easy access to the filter .
dispose of the fluid in your drain pan .

Steps.Text_raw: Now use your fluid extractor, or turkey baster (never use it in the kitchen again!) to remove enough fluid to get easy access to the filter. Dispose of the fluid in your drain pan.

Lines.Text: remove the filter using a pair of needle nose pliers .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the filter using a pair of needle nose pliers.

Lines.Text: see how nasty this is ? this may be the original filter , almost 30 years old . . .
nice fresh filter picture , ready for install .

Steps.Text_raw: See how nasty this is? This may be the original filter, almost 30 years old... Nice fresh filter picture, ready for install.

Lines.Text: with the filter out , you can remove the remainder of the fluid in the reservoir .

Steps.Text_raw: With the filter out, you can remove the remainder of the fluid in the reservoir.

Lines.Text: install your new filter . install it with the holes facing upwards , as shown .

Steps.Text_raw: Install your new filter. Install it with the holes facing upwards, as shown.

Lines.Text: replace the spring , retainer and nut over the filter and tighten down . the spring should still have some room to expand and contract but should be snug .
fill the reservoir to the bottom of the metal rim around the top of the pump housing .
this car is getting power steering fluid , instead of automatic transmission fluid . both are ok . the power steering fluid is clear .
now , turn on the engine . be sure the car is in park or neutral first . turn the steering wheel left and right , as far as it will go , a few times to get out any air .
top off the fluid as needed . never let the pump run dry .

if your fluid is very dirty , simply repeat the process of sucking out fluid , putting the filter back in , filling the reservoir , and then running the engine and turning the wheel until it looks clean .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the spring, retainer and nut over the filter and tighten down. The spring should still have some room to expand and contract but should be snug. Fill the reservoir to the bottom of the metal rim around the top of the pump housing. This car is getting power steering fluid, instead of automatic transmission fluid. Both are OK. The power steering fluid is clear. Now, turn on the engine. Be sure the car is in park or neutral first. Turn the steering wheel left and right, as far as it will go, a few times to get out any air. Top off the fluid as needed. Never let the pump run dry. If your fluid is very dirty, simply repeat the process of sucking out fluid, putting the filter back in, filling the reservoir, and then running the engine and turning the wheel until it looks clean.

Title: Mercedes W123 Diesel Fuel Filter, Secondary Replacement

Lines.Text: shown here is the large secondary fuel filter on a w123 diesel . it looks similar to oil filters you may have seen on other cars .

Steps.Text_raw: Shown here is the large secondary fuel filter on a W123 diesel. It looks similar to oil filters you may have seen on other cars.

Lines.Text: begin by loosening the large bolt on the top of the filter housing . there are two styles . this one is a later style , that has a 24 mm bolt . an earlier style uses a 22 mm bolt . you'll need to verify yours before beginning .
once the bolt begins to loosen , you'll need to use your other hand to hold the filter .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by loosening the large bolt on the top of the filter housing. There are two styles. This one is a later style, that has a 24mm bolt. An earlier style uses a 22mm bolt. You'll need to verify yours before beginning. Once the bolt begins to loosen, you'll need to use your other hand to hold the filter.

Lines.Text: once the bolt is fully removed , you can now carefully remove the old filter . be aware that fuel is at the very top of the filter and may spill if you tip it .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the  bolt is fully removed, you can now carefully remove the old filter. Be aware that fuel is at the very top of the filter and may spill if you tip it.

Lines.Text: inspect the bolt . on the newer style , as pictured , there are two different sizes of o-rings to seal the bolt . one the earlier style , there is only one o-ring .
on this bolt , the o-rings are old , brittle , and flattened . they need to be replaced , there are o-rings in most metric o-ring kits that will fit .
on the early style housing there is also a copper crush washer that goes under the head of the bolt , in place of the second o-ring . this should be replaced with every filter change .
see the new o-rings installed here .

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect the bolt. On the newer style, as pictured, there are two different sizes of o-rings to seal the bolt. One the earlier style, there is only one o-ring. On this bolt, the o-rings are old, brittle, and flattened. They need to be replaced, there are o-rings in most metric o-ring kits that will fit. On the early style housing there is also a copper crush washer that goes under the head of the bolt, in place of the second o-ring. This should be replaced with every filter change. See the new o-rings installed here.

Lines.Text: fill the new filter with fuel . diesel , or anything else that will burn safely in a diesel engine , such as virgin motor oil , virgin vegetable oil , clean automatic transmission fluid , or some diesel purge .
doing this will reduce the amount of fuel system priming that is necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: Fill the new filter with fuel. Diesel, or anything else that will burn safely in a diesel engine, such as virgin motor oil, virgin vegetable oil, clean automatic transmission fluid, or some diesel purge. Doing this will reduce the amount of fuel system priming that is necessary.

Lines.Text: re-install the filter , following this guide in reverse order .

Steps.Text_raw: Re-install the filter, following this guide in reverse order.

Lines.Text: prime the system using the primer pump until the fuel pressure release valve opens . you'll be able to tell by the squeaking noise from the injection pump .
now is also a good time to replace the clear plastic primary fuel filter . if you'd like to do this , and need guidance , guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Prime the system using the primer pump until the fuel pressure release valve opens. You'll be able to tell by the squeaking noise from the injection pump. Now is also a good time to replace the clear plastic primary fuel filter. If you'd like to do this, and need guidance, [guide|22553|see the primary fuel filter replacement guide].

Subject: Fuel Filter, Secondary

Lines.Text: begin by filling your power bleeder with a bottle , or two , of brake fluid .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by filling your power bleeder with a bottle, or two, of brake fluid.

Lines.Text: secure the top on the power bleeder .
then put the cap on the end of the hose securely on to your brake fluid reservoir opening .

Steps.Text_raw: Secure the top on the power bleeder. Then put the cap on the end of the hose securely on to your brake fluid reservoir opening.

Lines.Text: pump up the power bleeder . it may take a little while , especially if you've drained the system to replace hoses or something similar . keep an eye on the gauge . it doesn't take a lot of pressure , just 5 to 10 psi .

keep an eye around your brake fluid reservoir for leaks as you pump up the brake bleeder . the reservoir is not usually under pressure during use so leaks may show up where they hadn't before , especially in these two locations :
the sensor float caps on top of the reservoir
the rubber seals between the reservoir on the master cylinder

if you discover a leak you may need to stop the bleeding process to replace these bad seals . or , alternately , try a method of brake bleeding that does no use a pressure bleeder . you will need to research these methods elsewhere .

Steps.Text_raw: Pump up the power bleeder. It may take a little while, especially if you've drained the system to replace hoses or something similar. Keep an eye on the gauge. It doesn't take a lot of pressure, just 5 to 10 psi. Keep an eye around your brake fluid reservoir for leaks as you pump up the brake bleeder. The reservoir is not usually under pressure during use so leaks may show up where they hadn't before, especially in these two locations: The sensor float caps on top of the reservoir The rubber seals between the reservoir on the master cylinder If you discover a leak you may need to stop the bleeding process to replace these bad seals. Or, alternately, try a method of brake bleeding that does no use a pressure bleeder. You will need to research these methods elsewhere.

Lines.Text: find the bleed screw and nipple on the first wheel you'll want to bleed .
shown here are the bleed screws from the front , in red , and the rear , in green .
when flushing or bleeding your system , always start as far from the front of the car as possible . you should bleed your car in this sequence :
rear passenger side
rear driver's side
front passenger side
front driver's side

Steps.Text_raw: Find the bleed screw and nipple on the first wheel you'll want to bleed. Shown here are the bleed screws from the front, in red, and the rear, in green. When flushing or bleeding your system, always start as far from the front of the car as possible. You should bleed your car in this sequence: Rear passenger side Rear driver's side Front passenger side Front driver's side

Lines.Text: while it's possible to bleed your brakes with the wheels on the car , it's easier with the wheels off and it's definitely easier to show the process . . .
the next step is to slip your 9 mm wrench over the bleed screw .
then put the open end of your plastic hose on the nipple . the other should be secured inside your catch container . any type of bottle will work well . . .

Steps.Text_raw: While it's possible to bleed your brakes with the wheels on the car, it's easier with the wheels off and it's definitely easier to show the process... The next step is to slip your 9mm wrench over the bleed screw. Then put the open end of your plastic hose on the nipple. The other should be secured inside your catch container. Any type of bottle will work well...

Lines.Text: now open the bleed screw and watch as fluid begins to flow .

if you're flushing the system leave the line open until you see fresh fluid coming out . tip - buy fluid a different color than that currently in your car . doing so makes it very easy to tell when the fresh fluid reaches the end of the line .
if you're bleeding your system you'll want to leave the nipple open until you no longer see any air bubbles at all coming out of the bleed nipple .
repeat steps 5 and 6 on all four wheels using the sequence noted in step 4. it's recommended to go through the entire sequence twice .
be sure to keep an eye on the power bleeder during this process . do not let it de-pressurize or run dry ; either can allow air to enter the system and you'll need to start bleeding all over .

Steps.Text_raw: Now open the bleed screw and watch as fluid begins to flow. If you're flushing the system leave the line open until you see fresh fluid coming out. Tip - buy fluid a different color than that currently in your car. Doing so makes it very easy to tell when the fresh fluid reaches the end of the line. If you're bleeding your system you'll want to leave the nipple open until you no longer see any air bubbles at all coming out of the bleed nipple. Repeat steps 5 and 6 on all four wheels using the sequence noted in step 4. It's recommended to go through the entire sequence twice. Be sure to keep an eye on the power bleeder during this process. Do not let it de-pressurize or run dry; either can allow air to enter the system and you'll need to start bleeding all over.

Lines.Text: once you've finished bleeding , remove the power bleeder , being careful not to let the hose drip on your car's paint .
at this time your brake reservoir will be over-filled with brake fluid . it may actually spill over slightly when you remove the power bleeder . wipe this up right away with a shop towel or rag .
you'll now want to remove the excess fluid with a suction device . a turkey baster can be used , as long as you make sure to never use it in the kitchen again !
before you can insert the suction device , you'll need to lift out the screen in the fill neck of the brake fluid reservoir .
remove just enough fluid to get it down just below the max line .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you've finished bleeding, remove the power bleeder, being careful not to let the hose drip on your car's paint. At this time your brake reservoir will be over-filled with brake fluid. It may actually spill over slightly when you remove the power bleeder. Wipe this up right away with a shop towel or rag. You'll now want to remove the excess fluid with a suction device. A turkey baster can be used, as long as you make sure to never use it in the kitchen again! Before you can insert the suction device, you'll need to lift out the screen in the fill neck of the brake fluid reservoir. Remove just enough fluid to get it down just below the "MAX" line.

Lines.Text: close up the reservoir . wipe up any brake fluid that dripped . check all four bleed screws for any leaks and tighten if needed .
take the car for a test drive . go slowly at first . if the pedal feels soft or the brakes do not respond , stop the test drive , return to your work area and re-bleed .
if the test drive goes well , do another check for leaks when you return .

Steps.Text_raw: Close up the reservoir. Wipe up any brake fluid that dripped. Check all four bleed screws for any leaks and tighten if needed. Take the car for a test drive. Go slowly at first. If the pedal feels soft or the brakes do not respond, stop the test drive, return to your work area and re-bleed. If the test drive goes well, do another check for leaks when you return.

Lines.Text: don't let that bottle of brake fluid sit around long - in this bottle , it looks pretty refreshing ! and there's a convenient straw . . . .

Steps.Text_raw: Don't let that bottle of brake fluid sit around long - in this bottle, it looks pretty refreshing! And there's a convenient straw....

Lines.Text: before beginning you will need to remove the wheel ( s ) that are in the way of each brake hose you want to replace .

Steps.Text_raw: Before beginning you will need to remove the wheel(s) that are in the way of each brake hose you want to replace.

Lines.Text: before removing the hoses , the brake fluid on that caliper should be allowed to drain .
this is done through the bleed screw on each caliper . the following bleed screws are shown :
front caliper bleed screw
rear caliper bleed screw
allow the fluid to drain by loosening the screw just two or three turns until the fluid is dripping quickly . use a 9 mm box end wrench for this job .

Steps.Text_raw: Before removing the hoses, the brake fluid on that caliper should be allowed to drain. This is done through the bleed screw on each caliper.
