once you have done this , you should be able to see the internal components of the alternator , particularly the bridge assembly that houses the rectifier , voltage regulator and brushes .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull cover off the body of the alternator Once you have done this, you should be able to see the internal components of the alternator, particularly the bridge assembly that houses the rectifier, voltage regulator and brushes.

Lines.Text: with the alternator cover removed , use a 2 phillips screwdriver to remove the two , 6 mm screws that hold the brush cover in place .

remove the brush cover assembly from the alternator . you might need to insert a needle in the small hole to separate the brushes from the rotor . pull it out without using much force to avoid damage .
avoid disconnecting wires unless otherwise specified !

Steps.Text_raw: With the alternator cover removed, use a #2 Phillips screwdriver to remove the two, 6 mm screws that hold the brush cover in place. Remove the brush cover assembly from the alternator. You might need to insert a needle in the small hole to separate the brushes from the rotor. Pull it out without using much force to avoid damage. Avoid disconnecting wires unless otherwise specified!

Lines.Text: use a 2 phillips screwdriver to remove the two 6 mm screws holding down the voltage regulator
there are three screws that attach the voltage regulator to the bridge assembly . one of these screws was removed in the previous step .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a #2 Phillips screwdriver to remove the two 6mm screws holding down the voltage regulator There are three screws that attach the voltage regulator to the bridge assembly. One of these screws was removed in the previous step.

Lines.Text: locate and unscrew the 3 , 6 mm screws holding the bridge assembly in place
there are 4 screws attaching the bridge assembly to the alternator . one of these screws were removed in the previous step .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and unscrew the 3, 6mm screws holding the bridge assembly in place There are 4 screws attaching the bridge assembly to the alternator. One of these screws were removed in the previous step.

Lines.Text: locate the copper leads connecting the stator to the bridge assembly . there are 3 sets of 2 leads on the perimeter of the bridge , making 6 leads total .
these leads must be cut in order to remove the bridge from the alternator . these leads will have to be soldered back together on reassembly . keep the cut as clean as possible .
use wire cutters to cut all 6 of the leads on the perimeter of the bridge .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the copper leads connecting the stator to the bridge assembly. There are 3 sets of 2 leads on the perimeter of the bridge, making 6 leads total. These leads must be cut in order to remove the bridge from the alternator. These leads will have to be soldered back together on reassembly. Keep the cut as clean as possible. Use wire cutters to cut all 6 of the leads on the perimeter of the bridge.

Lines.Text: if necessary , use a pry bar to gently raise the top of the bridge assembly off the alternator
be extremely careful with the pry bar . excessive force will damage the bridge assembly .
make sure the cut ends of the copper leads are straight to make bridge assembly easier to pull off .

Steps.Text_raw: If necessary, use a pry bar to gently raise the top of the bridge assembly off the alternator Be extremely careful with the pry bar. Excessive force will damage the bridge assembly. Make sure the cut ends of the copper leads are straight to make bridge assembly easier to pull off.

Lines.Text: remove the lower section of the bridge assembly
use of a pry bar may be necessary . be gentle .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the lower section of the bridge assembly Use of a pry bar may be necessary. Be gentle.

Lines.Text: locate the small metal clasp attaching the voltage regulator to the the rectifier .
loosen the clasp using a pair of needle-nose pliers

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the small metal clasp attaching the voltage regulator to the the rectifier. Loosen the clasp using a pair of needle-nose pliers

Lines.Text: using a pair of wire cutters , cut the copper winding attaching the voltage regulator to the rectifier
be very careful with any cuts . keep them as clean as possible , as any severed connections will need to be soldered on reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a pair of wire cutters, cut the copper winding attaching the voltage regulator to the rectifier Be very careful with any cuts. Keep them as clean as possible, as any severed connections will need to be soldered on reassembly.

Lines.Text: remove the voltage regulator from the alternator
when connecting the new voltage regulator , carefully read the manufacturer's instructions on how to connect it to different types of alternators .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the voltage regulator from the alternator When connecting the new voltage regulator, carefully read the manufacturer's instructions on how to connect it to different types of alternators.

one of the nuts is placed underneath the l-bracket . remove the l-bracket and the 3 circled nuts before attempting to remove the remaining nut
there are two covers that need to be removed from the alternator . this step describes how to remove the back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove 4, 7.9mm  nuts using a 7.9mm socket driver head One of the nuts is placed underneath the L-Bracket. This step describes how to remove the back cover.

Lines.Text: pull cover off the body of the alternator
once you have done this , you should be able to see the internal components of the alternator , particularly the bridge assembly that houses the rectifier , voltage regulator and brushes .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull cover off the body of the alternator Once you have done this, you should be able to see the internal components of the alternator, particularly the bridge assembly that houses the rectifier, voltage regulator and brushes.

Lines.Text: you should now be able to see the recifier assembly , the brushes are located in the middle of the recifier assembly .
remove the brush assembly by unscrewing 2 , 6 mm center screws using a 2 phillips head screwdriver

Steps.Text_raw: You should now be able to see the recifier assembly, the brushes are located in the middle of the recifier assembly. Remove the brush assembly by unscrewing 2, 6mm center screws using a #2 Phillips head screw driver

Lines.Text: remove the brush assembly by pulling it out .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the brush assembly by pulling it out.

Lines.Text: inspect the brushes . if they are scored and not smooth you will need to replace the entire assembly .
when reinserting the brushes , make sure the springs keep the brushes in contact with the stator .

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect the brushes. If they are scored and not smooth you will need to replace the entire assembly. When reinserting the brushes, make sure the springs keep the brushes in contact with the stator.

Title: 2005-2007 Ford Freestyle AC Compressor Control Valve Replacement

Lines.Text: before getting started , go ahead and order a new ac compressor control valve . ebay is a good option and so is your favorite online auto parts retailer . search for dorman 917-275. about a 40 part . some local auto parts stores may carry this part as well . try napa .

Steps.Text_raw: Before getting started, go ahead and order a new AC Compressor Control Valve. eBay is a good option and so is your favorite online auto parts retailer. Search for "Dorman 917-275". About a $40 part. Some local auto parts stores may carry this part as well. Try NAPA.

Lines.Text: in order to replace the ac compressor control valve safely , the ac system will need to be depressurized . this is best done '''professionally''' to ensure the refrigerant is disposed of properly .
any automotive shop offering ac service can do this for half their 1 hour labor rate . in this case , 49 to evacuate the system .
ask the shop performing this procedure to provide you visual verification that your ac system has been completely evacuated . don't be shy .

Steps.Text_raw: In order to replace the AC Compressor Control Valve safely, the AC system will need to be depressurized. This is best done '''professionally''' to ensure the refrigerant is disposed of properly. Any automotive shop offering AC service can do this for half their 1 hour labor rate. In this case, $49 to evacuate the system. Ask the shop performing this procedure to provide you visual verification that your AC system has been completely evacuated. Don't be shy.

Lines.Text: now that the refrigerant has been removed professionally , it's your turn to go to work . pop the hood of a 2005-2007 ford freestyle , ford 500 , or mercury montego and you're looking at a 3.0 l v6 dohc 24 v duratec engine . this was the one and only engine option for these vehicles .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the refrigerant has been removed professionally, it's your turn to go to work. Pop the hood of a 2005-2007 Ford Freestyle, Ford 500, or Mercury Montego and you're looking at a 3.0L V6 DOHC 24V DURATEC engine. This was the one and only engine option for these vehicles.

Lines.Text: the ac compressor control valve is located behind a backing plate on the rear of the ac compressor . the ac compressor itself '''does not''' need to be removed . a short 10 mm box end wrench will get the job done . a ratchet and 10 mm socket will help .
since this step occurs adjacent to an exhaust manifold , use appropriate gloves to protect your skin from hot surfaces .
remove plate with bolts . set these items aside , they will be re-used . this is a good time to clean the plate and retaining bolts . a small amount of wd40 and shop towel will work fine .

Steps.Text_raw: The AC Compressor Control Valve is located behind a backing plate on the rear of the AC compressor. The AC compressor itself '''does not''' need to be removed. A short 10mm box end wrench will get the job done. A ratchet and 10mm socket will help. Since this step occurs adjacent to an exhaust manifold, use appropriate gloves to protect your skin from hot surfaces. Remove plate with bolts. Set these items aside, they will be re-used. This is a good time to clean the plate and retaining bolts. A small amount of WD40 and shop towel will work fine.

Lines.Text: removing the backing plate reveals the ac compressor control valve and seal .

using dexterous fingertips or a dental pick , slowly remove the ac compressor control valve and spring . use the dental pick to extrude the green rubber seal from its groove without marring the machined surface .
the used ac compressor control valve and seal are waste . keep the spring , it will be re-used .

Steps.Text_raw: Removing the backing plate reveals the AC Compressor Control Valve and seal. Using dexterous fingertips or a dental pick, slowly remove the AC Compressor Control Valve and spring. Use the dental pick to extrude the green rubber seal from its groove without marring the machined surface. The used AC Compressor Control Valve and seal are waste. Keep the spring, it will be re-used.

Lines.Text: a small amount of wd40 on a shop towel will work fine to clean the backing plate mating surface on the ac compressor .
wipe the surface clean of refrigerant and be careful not to knock any road grime into the ac compressor control valve housing .

Steps.Text_raw: A small amount of WD40 on a shop towel will work fine to clean the backing plate mating surface on the AC Compressor. Wipe the surface clean of refrigerant and be careful not to knock any road grime into the AC Compressor Control Valve housing.

Lines.Text: use a clean surface to layout everything needed to install the new ac compressor control valve and seal .
spring , backing plate , and bolts shown here are re-used .
attach spring to ac compressor control valve . the spring will simply snap into place with an interference fit .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a clean surface to layout everything needed to install the new AC Compressor Control Valve and seal. Spring, backing plate, and bolts shown here are re-used. Attach spring to AC Compressor Control Valve. The spring will simply snap into place with an interference fit.

Lines.Text: apply 2 drops of motor oil to the new seal and completely lubricate .
carefully press seal into groove without picking up any debris during the process .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply 2 drops of motor oil to the new seal and completely lubricate. Carefully press seal into groove without picking up any debris during the process.

Lines.Text: apply 3 drops of motor oil to the ac compressor control valve mating surface and completely lubricate .
the ac compressor control valve and spring assembly will install spring side first .
install the assembly without picking up any debris during the process .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply 3 drops of motor oil to the AC Compressor Control Valve mating surface and completely lubricate. The AC Compressor Control Valve and spring assembly will install spring side first. Install the assembly without picking up any debris during the process.

Lines.Text: there will be obvious witness marks on the backing plate indicating the install orientation of this part .
install backing plate hand tight .

Steps.Text_raw: There will be obvious witness marks on the backing plate indicating the install orientation of this part. Install backing plate hand tight.

Lines.Text: there is a module attached to the passenger side shock tower . start by removing the module's wiring harness .
next , use a standard sized flathead screwdriver to depress the clip holding the module to its mounting bracket .
carefully place the module out of the way .

Steps.Text_raw: There is a module attached to the passenger side shock tower. Start by removing the module's wiring harness. Next, use a standard sized flathead screwdriver to depress the clip holding the module to its mounting bracket. Carefully place the module out of the way.

Lines.Text: the ac low pressure port is now in plain sight . the port is covered by a black cap .
remove the black cap to reveal the port .

Steps.Text_raw: The AC low pressure port is now in plain sight.  The port is covered by a black cap. Remove the black cap to reveal the port.

Lines.Text: 2005-2007 ford freestyle , ford 500 , and mercury montego with front ac ( most ) use 29 ounces of r-134 a refrigerant .

for a front ac application start with 24 ounces or ( 2 ) 12 oz . cans of refrigerant . r-134 a refrigerant is available at any auto parts store in 12 oz . cans . you will need a separate dispenser like the one shown here by ez chill .
avoid stop leak refrigerant types and stick with untreated r-134 a refrigerant .

refrigerant cans are designed to be attached to the dispenser full and removed from the dispenser empty . proceed to thread the first can of refrigerant onto the dispenser . the dispenser will pierce and seal the can .
'''do not''' remove the refrigerant can from the dispenser until the can is completely empty .

Steps.Text_raw: 2005-2007 Ford Freestyle, Ford 500, and Mercury Montego with "Front AC" (most) use 29 ounces of R-134A refrigerant. For a Front AC application start with 24 ounces or (2) 12 oz. cans of refrigerant. R-134A refrigerant is available at any auto parts store in 12 oz. cans. You will need a separate dispenser like the one shown here by EZ Chill. Avoid "Stop Leak" refrigerant types and stick with untreated R-134A refrigerant. Refrigerant cans are designed to be attached to the dispenser full and removed from the dispenser empty. Proceed to thread the first can of refrigerant onto the dispenser. The dispenser will pierce and seal the can. '''Do not''' remove the refrigerant can from the dispenser until the can is completely empty.

Lines.Text: r-134 a ac systems use quick disconnect ports . to attach the dispenser , first compress the coupler .
when attaching coupler use a shop or plastic glove to protect your skin should any refrigerant discharge during the process .
next , cover the port squarely with coupler and release . nest can in a secure spot .

Steps.Text_raw: R-134A AC systems use quick disconnect ports. To attach the dispenser, first compress the coupler. When attaching coupler use a shop or plastic glove to protect your skin should any refrigerant discharge during the process. Next, cover the port squarely with coupler and release.  Nest can in a secure spot.

Lines.Text: start engine and let idle with transmission in park and parking brake engaged .
set ac to coldest setting and turn fan to high .

Steps.Text_raw: Start engine and let idle with transmission in park and parking brake engaged. Set AC to coldest setting and turn fan to high.

Lines.Text: pull trigger on dispenser while slowly clocking can back and forth until first can is completely empty .
attach second can of refrigerant and dispense until ac system holds steady at 40-45 psi . detach coupler .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull trigger on dispenser while slowly clocking can back and forth until first can is completely empty. Attach second can of refrigerant and dispense until AC system holds steady at 40-45 psi. Detach coupler.

Lines.Text: reinstall low pressure port cap .
reinstall module and reattach harness . you're done with the replacement .

Steps.Text_raw: Reinstall low pressure port cap. Reinstall module and reattach harness. You're done with the replacement.

Title: 2005 Dodge Grand Caravan Passenger Side Headlight Replacement

Lines.Text: open hood and locate the section that holds the passenger headlight .
remove the three bolts holding the headlight in place . note if they are rusted like mine were , be prepared to use some elbow grease .
put bolts off to the side for reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Open hood and locate the section that holds the passenger headlight. Remove the three bolts holding the headlight in place. *Note* If they are rusted like mine were, be prepared to use some elbow grease. Put bolts off to the side for reassembly.

Lines.Text: there is a red latch to release the hold on the connection . push that down then remove the cable attaching to the right turn signal's bulb . note you can remove just the cable or the bulb depending on your replacement .

the next cable is attached to main bulb in your headlight . twist the black circle around the cord counter clockwise and you can remove the bulb or just unclip the latch holding the cable in place . note my replacement came with bulbs so i just took the cable off .

Steps.Text_raw: There is a red latch to release the hold on the connection. Push that down then remove the cable attaching to the right turn signal's bulb. *Note* You can remove just the cable or the bulb depending on your replacement. The next cable is attached to main bulb in your headlight. Twist the black circle around the cord counter clockwise and you can remove the bulb OR just unclip the latch holding the cable in place. *Note* My replacement came with bulbs so I just took the cable off.

Lines.Text: push down on the gray insert that is holding the cables close to the headlight .
be careful with the cable to not bend or damage it .
now put the damaged headlight aside to properly dispose of .

Steps.Text_raw: Push down on the gray insert that is holding the cables close to the headlight. Be careful with the cable to not bend or damage it. Now put the damaged headlight aside to properly dispose of.

Lines.Text: now reattach all the cables careful by doing these instructions in reverse .

use the black handle , on top of the headlight , to help you align the holes to bolt the headlight in correctly . note i screwed them in a little in a time clockwise to align it properly and not to cross thread the bolts .
test the lights to assure they are coming on and enjoy your new headlight .

Steps.Text_raw: Now reattach all the cables careful by doing these instructions in reverse. Use the black handle, on top of the headlight, to help you align the holes to bolt the headlight in correctly. *Note* I screwed them in a little in a time clockwise to align it properly and not to cross thread the bolts. Test the lights to assure they are coming on and enjoy your new headlight.

Subject: Passenger Side Headlight

Lines.Text: the stop/turn signal bulb is located in the outer rear lamp unit that is secured at the rear of each quarter panel
open the tail gate and locate the two fasteners holding the light assembly to the quarter panel .
locate the notches in the outer ring of the fasteners . those are to facilitate the use of a screwdriver to remove the fasteners .

Steps.Text_raw: The stop/turn signal bulb is located in the outer rear lamp unit that is secured at the rear of each quarter panel Open the tail gate and locate the two fasteners holding the light assembly to the quarter panel. Locate the notches in the outer ring of the fasteners. Those are to facilitate the use of a screw driver to remove the fasteners.

Lines.Text: insert a flathead screwdriver or similar tool and pry out the center of the fastener
a pair of pliers , or similar tool , can be used to get a better hold on the fastener
completely remove the fastener

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a flathead screwdriver or similar tool and pry out the center of the fastener A pair of pliers, or similar tool, can be used to get a better hold on the fastener Completely remove the fastener

Lines.Text: proceed the same way with the bottom fastener . pry out the center .
use pliers or similar tool to pull the fastener
completely remove fastener

Steps.Text_raw: Proceed the same way with the bottom fastener. Pry out the center. Use pliers or similar tool to pull the fastener Completely remove fastener

Lines.Text: the tail light assembly is still held in place by two guide pegs . gently pull the complete assembly toward the rear of the vehicle to unseat the pegs .
fully remove the tail light assembly
the assembly can rest on the top of the rear bumper . the stop/turn signal bulb is the larger one of the two bulb fixtures .

Steps.Text_raw: The tail light assembly is still held in place by two guide pegs. Gently pull the complete assembly toward the rear of the vehicle to unseat the pegs. Fully remove the tail light assembly The assembly can rest on the top of the rear bumper. The Stop/Turn signal bulb is the larger one of the two bulb fixtures.

Lines.Text: remove the bulb socket by turning it about 1 /4 turn in a counter clockwise direction
remove the socket from the light assembly
remove the bulb from the socket by pulling it straight out .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bulb socket by turning it about 1/4 turn in a counter clockwise direction Remove the socket from the light assembly Remove the bulb from the socket by pulling it straight out.

Lines.Text: replace the burned out bulb with a new type 3057 dual filament bulb

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the burned out bulb with a new type 3057 dual filament bulb

Title: 2004 Mazda Tribute & Ford Escape - Ignition Coils and Spark Plugs Replacement on Cylinders 4  5 and 6

Lines.Text: 3 5 /16 screws hold the shroud in place
loosen screws and remove or if you cant get the loose screws out because the holes are deep , cover the holes with tape and remove the shroud . you may have to wiggle it to get it out

Steps.Text_raw: 3  5/16 screws hold the shroud in place Loosen Screws and remove or if you cant get the loose screws out because the holes are deep, cover the holes with tape and remove the shroud.  you may have to wiggle it to get it out

Lines.Text: the image is marked for coils 4 , 5 and 6 which you will see once the shroud is off . you may as well replace all 3 but if money is a factor , then just replace the bad one .
press on the clip lock on the electrical cable where you see my thumb nail to release the lock and just pull to slide off .

Steps.Text_raw: The image is marked for coils 4, 5 and 6 which you will see once the shroud is off.  you may as well replace all 3 but if money is a factor, then just replace the bad one. Press on the clip lock on the electrical cable where you see my thumb nail to release the lock and just pull to slide off.

Lines.Text: remove the 3 bolts that holds the 3 coils in place
if the bolts are tight because they've been in a while , use pb blaster to penetrate and give it some time to loosen . pb blaster is better than wd-40
then pull the coils straight out . there might be a little resistance as it separates from the spark plug but it should just come right out .
coils have a plastic top with an electrical connector and a rubber boot on the bottom . this eliminates the old style when we used to have a cap and wires to make the connection

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 3 bolts that holds the 3 coils in place If the bolts are tight because they've been in a while, use pb blaster to penetrate and give it some time to loosen. pb blaster is better than wd-40 then pull the coils straight out. There might be a little resistance as it separates from the spark plug but it should just come right out. Coils have a plastic top with an electrical connector and a rubber boot on the bottom. This eliminates the old style when we used to have a cap and wires to make the connection

Lines.Text: make sure you use an actual spark plug socket that has a rubber insert so that the plug will come out with the socket .
take note of the direction of the plugs when you take them out , gap / screw side down
the new plugs wont need to be gapped .
loosen slowly and when tightening , tighten slowly . do not over tighten .
i used ena brand coils that i got on amazon . was 6 for 45 and the plugs were 38.

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure you use an actual spark plug socket that has a rubber insert so that the plug will come out with the socket. Take note of the direction of the plugs when you take them out, gap / screw side down The new plugs wont need to be gapped. Loosen slowly and when tightening, tighten slowly. Do not over tighten. I used ENA brand coils that I got on Amazon. Was 6 for $45 and the plugs were $38.

Lines.Text: assemble in reverse order . when properly seated and bolted back in , coils should be all the way down so the anchor bolt and plastic head of the coil is flush with the engine where it is seated .

the bolt should be tight but do not over tighten . you may want to put a tiny tiny bit of pb blaster on the bolt to help it especially if it squeels as you tighten it . you don't want to break the bolt or over tighten .

after everything is back together test drive the car . you should notice that the misfires are gone but the check engine light wont go out until the car has enough recordings of no-misfires usually several 20 minute drives .

Steps.Text_raw: Assemble in reverse order. When properly seated and bolted back in,  coils should be all the way down so the anchor bolt and plastic head of the coil is flush with the engine where it is seated. The bolt should be tight but do not over tighten. you may want to put a tiny tiny bit of pb blaster on the bolt to help it especially if it squeels as you tighten  it. You don't want to break the bolt or over tighten. After everything is back together test drive the car. You should notice that the misfires are gone but the check engine light wont go out until the car has enough recordings of no-misfires usually several 20 minute drives.

Subject: Ignition Coils and Spark Plugs

Lines.Text: begin by applying the parking brake . the parking brake is located below the left side of the driver's console . push it down until it is fully engaged .
locate the 14 mm hex oil drain plug . the drain plug is underneath the truck in the middle of the plate after the skid plate .
place an oil drain pan under the oil drain plug .
be sure to position the drain pan so that it will catch the oil when it is streaming out of the pan .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by applying the parking brake. The parking brake is located  below the left side of the driver's console. Push it down until it is fully engaged. Locate the 14 mm hex oil drain plug. The drain plug is underneath the truck in the middle of the plate after the skid plate. Place an oil drain pan under the oil drain plug. Be sure to position the drain pan so that it will catch the oil when it is streaming out of the pan.

Lines.Text: always wear protective gloves and eyewear when working with motor oil . be careful if your car has been running recently as the engine , transmission , and exhaust may be very hot . keep rags or towels nearby to wipe up any spills .
use a 14 mm box end wrench or socket wrench to loosen the oil drain plug by turning it counter-clockwise until you can turn it by hand .
finish removing the oil drain plug by hand to allow the oil to drain .
watch the draining oil for shiny specks . the shiny specks may be metal flakes and could mean there is a serious problem with your engine internals .

Steps.Text_raw: Always wear protective gloves and eyewear when working with motor oil. Be careful if your car has been running recently as the engine, transmission, and exhaust may be very hot. Keep rags or towels nearby to wipe up any spills. Use a 14 mm box end wrench or socket wrench to loosen the oil drain plug by turning it counter-clockwise until you can turn it by hand. Finish removing the oil drain plug by hand to allow the oil to drain. Watch the draining oil for shiny specks. The shiny specks may be metal flakes and could mean there is a serious problem with your engine internals.

Lines.Text: clean the drain plug and gasket .
remove the gasket from the drain plug and inspect both parts for damage . replace either part if necessary .

if there is no gasket on the drain plug , check the oil pan of the truck to see if it is stuck . if it is , you can use the drain plug or a blade screwdriver to pull it off . be careful to not damage the gasket or oil pan when removing a stuck gasket .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean the drain plug and gasket. Remove the gasket from the drain plug and inspect both parts for damage. Replace either part if necessary. If there is no gasket on the drain plug, check the oil pan of the truck to see if it is stuck. If it is, you can use the drain plug or a blade screw driver to pull it off. Be careful to not damage the gasket or oil pan when removing a stuck gasket.

Lines.Text: once the draining oil has slowed to a drip , put the oil drain plug back into its hole and turn it clockwise by hand as far as possible .
continue turning the drain plug clockwise with a 14 mm box end wrench or socket until it is snug .
only tighten the drain plug until it is snug . over-tightening the oil drain plug can strip the threads or crack the oil pan .
wipe off any oil left on the oil pan with a clean rag or towel .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the draining oil has slowed to a drip, put the oil drain plug back into its hole and turn it clockwise by hand as far as possible. Continue turning the drain plug clockwise with a 14 mm box end wrench or socket until it is snug. Only tighten the drain plug until it is snug. Over-tightening the oil drain plug can strip the threads or crack the oil pan. Wipe off any oil left on the oil pan with a clean rag or towel.

Lines.Text: locate the four 12 mm hex bolts holding the skid plate to the chassis .
support the skid plate with one hand and use a 12 mm socket wrench to turn the four bolts counter-clockwise until they come out .
be cautious and alert while removing the skid plate . the skid plate or any debris trapped inside may fall on you .
lower the skid plate from the underside of the truck and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the four 12 mm hex bolts holding the skid plate to the chassis. Support the skid plate with one hand and use a 12 mm socket wrench to turn the four bolts counter-clockwise until they come out. Be cautious and alert while removing the skid plate. The skid plate or any debris trapped inside may fall on you. Lower the skid plate from the underside of the truck and set it aside.

Lines.Text: locate the oil filter . it is on the driver's side of the oil pan and above the steering linkages .
slide the oil drain pan below the oil filter so that it will catch any oil that drips down when the oil filter is removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the oil filter. It is on the driver's side of the oil pan and above the steering linkages. Slide the oil drain pan below the oil filter so that it will catch any oil that drips down when the oil filter is removed.

Lines.Text: turn the oil filter counter-clockwise by hand until it comes off the engine's oil filter threads .
if the filter is too tight to turn by hand , use an oil filter wrench .
lower the oil filter out of the engine bay with the threaded end facing up to reduce the amount of oil spilled .
place the oil filter into the oil drain pan with its open end facing down .
wipe off the engine's oil filter gasket face with a clean rag or towel .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the oil filter counter-clockwise by hand until it comes off the engine's oil filter threads. If the filter is too tight to turn by hand, use an oil filter wrench. Lower the oil filter out of the engine bay with the threaded end facing up to reduce the amount of oil spilled. Place the oil filter into the oil drain pan with its open end facing down. Wipe off the engine's oil filter gasket face with a clean rag or towel.

Lines.Text: pour a small amount of oil into the lid of the oil bottle .
dip a clean , gloved finger into the lid with oil .
use your wetted finger to spread a thin layer of oil onto the gasket of the new oil filter .
fill the oil filter 1 /3 of the way full with new oil . this will ensure the truck has oil as soon as the truck is started .

Steps.Text_raw: Pour a small amount of oil into the lid of the oil bottle. Dip a clean, gloved finger into the lid with oil. Use your wetted finger to spread a thin layer of oil onto the gasket of the new oil filter. Fill the oil filter 1/3 of the way full with new oil. This will ensure the truck has oil as soon as the truck is started.

Lines.Text: place the threaded end of the oil filter onto the engine's oil filter threads , being careful to not get dirt or debris on the filter's gasket .
turn the filter clockwise by hand until it is snug .
if the filter is difficult to turn at the beginning of its threads , stop ! you may be cross threading the oil filter . re-align the oil filter and try again .
do not over-tighten your oil filter by using a wrench . doing so may cause the oil filter seal to leak and will make removing the oil filter very difficult in the future .
remove the oil drain pan from underneath the truck .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the threaded end of the oil filter onto the engine's oil filter threads, being careful to not get dirt or debris on the filter's gasket. Turn the filter clockwise by hand until it is snug. If the filter is difficult to turn at the beginning of its threads, stop! You may be cross threading the oil filter. Re-align the oil filter and try again. Do not over-tighten your oil filter by using a wrench. Doing so may cause the oil filter seal to leak and will make removing the oil filter very difficult in the future. Remove the oil drain pan from underneath the truck.

Lines.Text: put the skid plate back into place and support it with one hand . use your other hand to reinsert the 12 mm bolts , turning them clockwise about two turns .
make sure the two tabs on the skid plate are inserted into their respective holes as indicated in picture 2.
use the 12 mm socket wrench to finish turning the bolts clockwise until they are snug .

Steps.Text_raw: Put the skid plate back into place and support it with one hand. Use your other hand to reinsert the 12 mm bolts, turning them clockwise about two turns. Make sure the two tabs on the skid plate are inserted into their respective holes as indicated in picture 2. Use the 12 mm socket wrench to finish turning the bolts clockwise until they are snug.

Lines.Text: locate the hood release lever . it is below the left side of the driver's console . pull it until you hear the hood click .
go to the front of the truck and locate the hood release latch . it will be under the hood and slightly towards the driver's side of the truck .
use one hand to lift up on the latch and your other hand to lift the hood open .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the hood release lever. It is below the left side of the driver's console. Pull it until you hear the hood click. Go to the front of the truck and locate the hood release latch. It will be under the hood and slightly towards the driver's side of the truck. Use one hand to lift up on the latch and your other hand to lift the hood open.

Lines.Text: locate the oil filler cap on the driver's side valve cover .
turn the cap counter-clockwise , then pull it off the valve cover .
insert funnel .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the oil filler cap on the driver's side valve cover. Turn the cap counter-clockwise, then pull it off the valve cover. Insert funnel.

Lines.Text: pour 6.5 quarts of 5 w-30 automobile oil into the engine . use one hand to stabilize the funnel to help prevent spills .
consult your owner's manual if you think your operating conditions call for a different oil viscosity .
remove the funnel and put the oil filler cap back over the oil filler hole . turn the cap clockwise until it is snug and you hear a click .

Steps.Text_raw: Pour 6.5 quarts of 5W-30 automobile oil into the engine. Use one hand to stabilize the funnel to help prevent spills. Consult your owner's manual if you think your operating conditions call for a different oil viscosity. Remove the funnel and put the oil filler cap back over the oil filler hole. Turn the cap clockwise until it is snug and you hear a click.

Lines.Text: locate the yellow oil dipstick next to the passenger's side valve cover .
do not confuse the oil dipstick for the transmission fluid dipstick , which has an orange handle and is in the same general area .
pull out the oil dipstick , wipe it off , place it all the way back into its hole , and remove it again .
check the oil level on the end of the dipstick . it should be within the two holes , or slightly above the top most hole .

this is not your actual oil level , but a pre-check to make sure the engine will not run dry when you first start it . the oil level will drop slightly after the first run when oil completely fills the new oil filter .
add oil if the oil level is below the bottom most hole of the dipstick . place the oil dipstick all the way back in its hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the yellow oil dipstick next to the passenger's side valve cover. Do not confuse the oil dipstick for the transmission fluid dipstick, which has an orange handle and is in the same general area. Pull out the oil dipstick, wipe it off, place it all the way back into its hole, and remove it again. Check the oil level on the end of the dipstick. It should be within the two holes, or slightly above the top most hole. This is not your actual oil level, but a pre-check to make sure the engine will not run dry when you first start it. The oil level will drop slightly after the first run when oil completely fills the new oil filter. Add oil if the oil level is below the bottom most hole  of the dipstick. Place the oil dipstick all the way back in its hole.

Lines.Text: gently lower the hood until it clicks into the secondary latch .
press firmly on the edge of the hood until you hear the primary latch engage .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lower the hood until it clicks into the secondary latch. Press firmly on the edge of the hood until you hear the primary latch engage.

Lines.Text: start the truck and look for leaks underneath it . if there are leaks , shut the truck off and determine if the drain plug or filter need to be tightened .

after running the engine for a few minutes , let it cool down for at least 15 minutes re-check the oil level . if the oil level is more than a 1 /2 above the top hole of the dipstick you will need to drain oil . if the oil level is below the bottom hole of the dipstick you will need to add oil .
allow 12-24 hours for all the oil to drain out of your old oil filter .

take your old oil and filter to a recycling facility . most auto parts stores and repair shops accept these at no charge . some cities and/or counties have a service where they will collect used oil and filters from your home . for more information , see the american petroleum institute's web page on used motor oil collection and recycling .

Steps.Text_raw: Start the truck and look for leaks underneath it. If there are leaks, shut the truck off and determine if the drain plug or filter need to be tightened. After running the engine for a few minutes, let it cool down for at least 15 minutes re-check the oil level. If the oil level is more than a 1/2" above the top hole of the dipstick you will need to drain oil. If the oil level is below the bottom hole of the dipstick you will need to add oil. Allow 12-24 hours for all the oil to drain out of your old oil filter. Take your old oil and filter to a recycling facility. Most auto parts stores and repair shops accept these at no charge. Some cities and/or counties have a service where they will collect used oil and filters from your home. For more information, see the American Petroleum Institute's web page on used motor oil collection and recycling.

Title: AUX Audio Input Repair for  2009-2013 Toyota Corolla

Lines.Text: don't be afraid to use extra force to get these components to open .
1 ) there is two side of the component to remove for the first picture
before removing component in the third picture , there are two screws to be removed ( one on each side ) .

Lines.Text: pull the component out in the first picture with force !
reach underneath the white component connected to wire and along there , push to remove it from the aux component ( black rectangle thing )
once the white component detached , simply push aux component out ( toward you ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the component out in the first picture with force! Reach underneath the white component connected to wire and along there, push to remove it from the AUX component (black rectangle thing) Once the white component detached, simply push AUX component out (toward you).

Lines.Text: apply pressure where the toothpick is pointing and remove the cap at the same time . ( can get tricky )
finally , like the third picture , remove the aux circuit with force but try to be gentle also .

Steps.Text_raw: Apply pressure where the toothpick is pointing and remove the cap at the same time. (Can get tricky) Finally, like the third picture, remove the AUX circuit with force but try to be gentle also.

Steps.Text_raw: The center pin is located where the red circle is at on the picture

Lines.Text: soldering does not have to be perfect as long as it connects the two pin we located in the previous picture .

Title: 1999 Buick Century Window Regulator and Motor Replacement

Lines.Text: lower window to about ¾ of the way down or until the frame that the window sits on is visible in the lower opening .

Steps.Text_raw: Lower window to about ¾ of the way down or until the frame that the window sits on is visible in the lower opening.

Lines.Text: locate the 3 screws in the door .
1 screw is in the door latch ( phillips head )
the other 2 are in the door tray ( 10 mm socket )

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the 3 screws in the door. 1 screw is  in the door latch (phillips head) The other 2 are in the door tray (10mm socket)

Lines.Text: pry away the door ( a flat head can be used as seen in the image , but any wedge like object would work . )

Steps.Text_raw: Pry away the door (a flat head can be used as seen in the image, but any wedge like object would work.)

Lines.Text: tweeter connection ( circled in red )
disconnect the tweeter connection where the red arrow is pointing .
automatic lock connection ( circled in green )
disconnect the automatic lock connection from its location in the green circle .

Steps.Text_raw: Tweeter Connection (circled in red) Disconnect the tweeter connection where the red arrow is pointing. Automatic Lock Connection (circled in green) Disconnect the automatic lock connection from its location in the green circle.

Lines.Text: if the internal door panel is covered with protective plastic , remove it before proceeding .

Steps.Text_raw: If the internal door panel is covered with protective plastic, remove it before proceeding.

Lines.Text: locate and remove the 3 screws holding the window motor in place ( wrench and 10 mm socket needed ) .
disconnect the window motor connection wiring .
wedge in-between the outer shell of the door and the window to hold the window in place ( be careful not to damage the window . may have to stick it in at an angle ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and remove the 3 screws holding the window motor in place (Wrench and 10mm socket needed). Disconnect the window motor connection wiring. Wedge in-between the outer shell of the door and the window to hold the window in place (be careful not to damage the window. May have to stick it in at an angle).

Lines.Text: locate and remove the four 10 mm screws below the interior door latch .
locate and remove the two 10 mm screws on the window frame .
remove the motor and the regulator through the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and Remove the four 10mm screws below the interior door latch. Locate and remove the two 10mm screws on the window frame. Remove the motor and the regulator through the hole.

Lines.Text: follow steps in reverse order to connect the new window motor and regulator and to reassemble the door panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Follow steps in reverse order to connect the new window motor and regulator and to reassemble the door panel.

Lines.Text: this guide only applies to floor-shift automatics , such as my 1976 230.6 ( 114.015 )
this car was never sold in usa , as i'm in new zealand , but the centre-console is the same for all the other 114 and 115 automatics ( and probably other model ranges )
first step is to open and remove your ashtray to gain access to the first set of screws
push down on the metal tab - while pulling the ashtray out

Steps.Text_raw: This guide only applies to floor-shift automatics, such as my 1976 230.6 (114.015) This car was never sold in USA, as I'm in New Zealand, but the centre-console is the same for all the other 114 and 115 automatics (and probably other model ranges) First step is to open and remove your Ashtray to gain access to the first set of screws Push down on the metal tab - while pulling the ashtray out

Lines.Text: after you've removed the ashtray you'll see the ashtray frame/bracket
remove the two pan-head screws at the rear of the opening - ignore the two counter-sunk screws at the bottom for now
careful when you pull it out as the connector for the cigar lighter contacts on left sticks out so you can't just pull it straight-out

Steps.Text_raw: After you've removed the ashtray you'll see the ashtray frame/bracket Remove the two pan-head screws at the rear of the opening - ignore the two counter-sunk screws at the bottom for now Careful when you pull it out as the connector for the cigar lighter contacts on left sticks out so you can't just pull it straight-out

Lines.Text: now you can remove those two counter-sunk screws holding in the front of the shifter/center console panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Now you can remove those two counter-sunk screws holding in the front of the shifter/center console panel.

Lines.Text: the hardest , or second-hardest step
there is a simple metal trim clip holding the rear of the centre-console trim panel down ( marked by a yellow box in photo 2 )
you won't be able to see it easily , you can pry back the rubber trim in the marked area to gain a view of the clip ( blue box area in photo )
in my car the plastic foot with the metal clip attached to it is cracked , so i added a small bit of wire to help pull it out next time so as not to break it ( see red box in 3 rd photo )

Steps.Text_raw: The hardest, or second-hardest step There is a simple metal trim clip holding the rear of the centre-console trim panel down (marked by a yellow box in photo 2) You won't be able to see it easily, you can pry back the rubber trim in the marked area to gain a view of the clip (blue box area in photo) In my car the plastic foot with the metal clip attached to it is cracked, so I added a small bit of wire to help pull it out next time so as not to break it (see red box in 3rd photo)

Lines.Text: ensure your handbrake is set , or you're not on a slope
shift to neutral or other gears as required to get the console panel out
you'll need to angle the trim panel back and forth a little as the plugs for your hazards and rear defroster/demister get in the way
i've shown the units and their plugs in yellow ( demister ) and red ( hazards )

Steps.Text_raw: Ensure your handbrake is set, or you're not on a slope Shift to neutral or other gears as required to get the console panel out You'll need to angle the trim panel back and forth a little as the plugs for your hazards and rear defroster/demister get in the way I've shown the units and their plugs in Yellow (demister) and Red (hazards)

Lines.Text: it's simply clipped-in and you can pry using a small flat-head at the top to get it started
when you're re-installing it , you simply line up the v symbol on the shifter housing with the v symbol on the lamp holder

Steps.Text_raw: It's simply clipped-in and you can pry using a small flat-head at the top to get it started When you're re-installing it, you simply line up the V symbol on the shifter housing with the V symbol on the lamp holder

Lines.Text: you'll need a 10 mm socket - i used a 1 /4 in deep
there are 3 bolts , one on the right-side and 2 on the left
they have a small wavy washer , don't drop it down the centre-console when you pull them out
you won't be able to remove the surround fully until the next step

Steps.Text_raw: You'll need a 10mm socket - I used a 1/4in deep There are 3 bolts, one on the right-side and 2 on the left They have a small wavy washer, don't drop it down the centre-console when you pull them out You won't be able to remove the surround fully until the next step

Lines.Text: first loosen the 15 mm jam nut ( outlined in red )
now you can unscrew the shift lever/knob
when you're re-installing it ensure it's clocked correctly before tightening the jam nut

Steps.Text_raw: First loosen the 15mm jam nut (outlined in red) Now you can unscrew the shift lever/knob When you're re-installing it ensure it's clocked correctly before tightening the jam nut

Lines.Text: there are four 10 mm bolts , the left two bolts are hard to see , you'll need to pry the trim back a bit
the top-left bolt has the ground cable for the shifter backlight on it
the bolts have large flat washers on them , be careful not to drop them down the side of the console - use a magnet if necessary

Steps.Text_raw: There are four 10mm bolts, the left two bolts are hard to see, you'll need to pry the trim back a bit The top-left bolt has the ground cable for the shifter backlight on it The bolts have large flat washers on them, be careful not to drop them down the side of the console - use a magnet if necessary

Lines.Text: after lifting up the shifter housing ( black plastic part ) you'll see it's attached to the shift rod below
the green thing in the picture is the driveshaft
to get better access , you can pull the shift rod towards the rear of the car ( go through a few gears ) as i did
the clip is fairly easy to remove with needle nose pliers and/or a small flat-head screwdriver
be careful not to drop the clip down the side of the centre console or through the hole in the tunnel now revealed
these photos are actually from re-assembly , as you can see i lubed up all bushings with 3 m silicone paste - you could use any plastic-safe lube

Steps.Text_raw: After lifting up the shifter housing (black plastic part) you'll see it's attached to the shift rod below The green thing in the picture is the driveshaft To get better access, you can pull the shift rod towards the rear of the car (go through a few gears) as I did The clip is fairly easy to remove with needle nose pliers and/or a small flat-head screwdriver Be careful not to drop the clip down the side of the centre console or through the hole in the tunnel now revealed These photos are actually from re-assembly, as you can see I lubed up all bushings with 3M Silicone paste - you could use any plastic-safe lube

Lines.Text: you'll see a plastic half-moon part ( to stop dust and noise from entering the car ) - it just pulls out

Steps.Text_raw: You'll see a plastic half-moon part (to stop dust and noise from entering the car) - it just pulls out

Lines.Text: remove a clip from one end of the small rod connecting the shift lever yoke to the main rod
again as these photos were taken during re-assembly there is silicone lube present
you can see there is a tiny bushing in between the spring and the small rod on each end - these bushing are optional but cheap , mine were completely gone
the small bushing part number is : 1152670950
i used a small screwdriver and needle-nose pliers to remove the clip ( slide in direction of red arrow )

Steps.Text_raw: Remove a clip from one end of the small rod connecting the shift lever yoke to the main rod Again as these photos were taken during re-assembly there is silicone lube present You can see there is a tiny bushing in between the spring and the small rod on each end - these bushing are optional but cheap, mine were completely gone The small bushing part number is: 1152670950 I used a small screwdriver and needle-nose pliers to remove the clip (slide in direction of red arrow)

Lines.Text: some better views of those tiny bushings as you pull the small rod out ( slide rod out in direction of arrow )
these photos were during re-assembly so the bushing is fresh and clear , the old ones would probably be yellowed or cracked or missing
i put a blue circle on one end of the small rod and a red circle on the other end so you can identify them better
i used again the small screwdriver and needle-nose pliers to pry the spring back while re-inserting the bushings

Steps.Text_raw: Some better views of those tiny bushings as you pull the small rod out (slide rod out in direction of arrow) These photos were during re-assembly so the bushing is fresh and clear, the old ones would probably be yellowed or cracked or missing I put a blue circle on one end of the small rod and a red circle on the other end so you can identify them better I used again the small screwdriver and needle-nose pliers to pry the spring back while re-inserting the bushings

Lines.Text: and a final show of parts involved to attach/detach the yoke from the shaft

Lines.Text: now the hardest or second-hardest step
removing the snap-ring
if you have small snap-ring pliers this is probably pretty easy
if not you might be lucky like i was and the needle-nose tips fit into the holes
even so it was a challenge to install and remove the snap-ring
also the part will probably go flying , so do the disassembly in a place where you can find it if it goes flying
the washer goes under the snap ring
as you can see these photos are from re-assembly , my old bushing was yellowed and the left-side in pieces

Steps.Text_raw: Now the hardest or second-hardest step Removing the snap-ring If you have small snap-ring pliers this is probably pretty easy If not you might be lucky like I was and the needle-nose tips fit into the holes Even so it was a challenge to install and remove the snap-ring Also the part will probably go flying, so do the disassembly in a place where you can find it if it goes flying The washer goes under the snap ring As you can see these photos are from re-assembly, my old bushing was yellowed and the left-side in pieces

here you'll see why you had to remove the plastic half-moon part
after you've got it all apart , the bushings ( if any remain ) should just push out
i cleaned up and then lubed the parts before reassembling
